reviewText:
THE WITCHER 2: ASSASSINS OF KINGS ENHANCED EDITION
REVIEW



The Witcher 2, even before entering the main menu, shows us maybe the best CG intro ever in a video game. After the shocking ending of The Witcher leaving us with a cliffhanger, The Witcher 2 starts shortly after the predecessor. Geralt of Rivia, after saving King Foltest of Temeria, works for him now, as a personal bodyguard. Hunting traitors, Foltest sieges a castle and “invite” Geralt to help his army. Something shocking happens in the action-packed epic prologue, and now Geralt must prove he is saying the truth, and have his vengeance, seeking a mysterious man. The Witcher 2 storyline is more action-packed than the first one. It’s epic, it’s complex and have a lot of politics involved. Also, you have to make dramatic choices, that even before the half of the game, show a totally different perception of the entire story, making it almost two in one. (Beat the game two times for the full experience!) Personally, I prefer the first Witcher story, but the second one is really better in showing it’s themes and involves a lot of more things happening in the world, with decisions that matter even in The Witcher 3, drawing to one possible conclusion, showed in an epic CG. The ending does not disappoint and put another cliffhanger that serve as a promise for the epic The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, the conclusion of the saga. Character development is very good and you will possible love two characters, Saskia and Ioverth. They’re amazing and shows a good background. But… it’s The Witcher! Everyone have their own personal story and unique quests, everything in the world have something behind it. The game’s campaign is shorter than the first one, because is kind of divided in two, but its more action packed like I also said and includes even more epic Boss Battles, that I bet will surprise you. Besides the campaign being smaller, the game itself is bigger, have more quests, bigger areas to explore and more content! The graphics are impressive, as still of today. The darker style of the game shows beautiful scenarios and regions, and well done animations, a problem from the first game. Alongside the epic soundtrack and sound effects, it all boils down to the amazing fantasy atmosphere the game shows you. The movimentation is more fluid than in the first game and you can even climb some obstacles. Combine this with combat that also shows an amazing innovation. Maybe the worst aspect of the first game, turned in one of the triumphs in The Witcher 2. The combat combines the Signs again, but now it’s not a totally combo-based like the first one and have a lot of movements and sounds like more a hack’n’slash game, with truly epic fight scenes with all kinds of monsters, that are now bigger in number than on the first game. Contracts are back as always and you have to clean monster nests and destroy them. As this is the enhanced edition, it features better graphics, bugs correction, and all of the released DLC, so you may find trolls in the game world with some interesting stories, and there is also the special Arena mode where you fight waves of enemies. Talking about the game itself again, there’s a lot of weapons again, and this time, a lot of armors, something I found lacking in the first. You can breed potions as always that help you in combat and sometimes is even necessary for quests. The world feels alive and you have a lot of romance options, but this time with no romance cards, but explicit scenes, even more than its successor, including specially one with Triss…There is also a crafting system for the armor and weapons which gives you the best ones in the game. Now you can meditate (to pass time and brew potions) anywhere if there’s no enemies, so it’s more practical than the predecessor. Dice poker is present: you can play a game with almost everyone and it's very fun and have quests related. The perk and level up system is cool and works well. The bad aspects for the game includes some bugs, random crashes that make you lose your progress and even lose your save in some cases (do a lot of them) and the lack of “RPG interactions”. The first one had a lot of food, drinks that you could eat and an animation was showed. This one does not feature all of that and no animations are present. Ok, that's a minor thing but...my opinion. Another thing is the game can be too punitive at the beggining, not stimulating someone into proceeding in. After you level up a bit it becomes fun, however. Mini games are present in boss battles. And they are annoying. The inventory menus are kind of chunky for me, also.

+High Replayability
+Choices and consequences
+Epic story with political background
+Epic and amazing soundtrack and sound effects
+Big Immersion
+Customization, lots of weapons, armors and skills
+Top quality realtime weather and passage of time
+Charismatic characters
+Beautiful scenarios with large areas
+A lot of sidequests and talk
+Cool scenarios
+Variety of monsters even a dragon!
+Lots of content
+Fun combat
+Romance scenes
+Epic CGI in the start and in the end of the game.
+Level up system
+Dice poker
+Boss battles
+Arena mode

-Some bugs
-Random crashes
-Annoying boss battles mini-games
-Lack of minor details
-Over-punitive beggining
-A bit chunky inventory menus


Va fail, Gwynbleidd. The Witcher 2 takes everything the first did right. And do it better. To be continued.
9,5/10

reviewText:
The Witcher 2 as a game is the meaning of the word progress. Everything from the graphics to the systems behind the game are an amazing feat, one you would expect from a big named developer backed up by a huge budget. The looks of the game are not only unparalleled due to its PC only nature, but also because it presents a world that feels hand crafted. The attention to detail borders on the extreme: the clothes, the houses and buildings, the faces of the characters their weapons and in general every corner, nook and cranny of the world has a distinctive touch. The scenery is simply breathtaking, and if you are like me you will want to make a screenshot out of every frame. It also shows that you don't need an overabundance of browns and blood reds in your palette to show a gritty dark fantasy world. This game shows its maturity not through a pretense of adult topics or over the top action animations, but through a careful use of its elements and by showing the player some respect: yes, you are an adult, and you can handle these topics, because indeed the Witcher's is a dark world filled with conspiracies, racism and characters in between every single shade of gray. It is a living, breathing, unforgiving world.
The story is as complex as in the first game, filled with twists and choices that may change the fate of many, and forking paths that make a replay of the game not only encouraged, but required in order to see the extent to which they occur and diverge. Normal and hard difficulties are recommended and will test your skills if you don't face every battle with all seriousness, preparing beforehand by brewing and drinking potions and using all of your abilities during the fight, i.e. your swords your magic signs depending on what enemy you face and traps and bombs for your crowd control.
The actual combat is in no way dumbed down. It will still punish you if you go unprepared and you can't mash your way out of battles. It is in much better shape than in the first game, and friendly to both the use of a gamepad or mouse and keyboard. The user interface is slick and great looking.
The ending of the game comes abruptly, and you might feel that it doesn't solve every issue the game presents (the main storyline issues ARE solved, though). It is no excuse from what many will consider a downbeat ending, but in all honesty it doesn't detract a single beat from what this game does right, which is almost everything else. Even if you don't like the ending you will feel that the journey was worth it.
In the end I feel like I'm required to praise this game so high despite its shortcomings not because it is a perfect game, but because it is an honest one. When more and more AAA releases are done with specific quarters or demographics numbers behind, or executives who never play games are calling the shots, The Witcher 2 really feels developed to please it audience, to show them they too are tired of these.
There is a certain level of quality you expect from bigger developers which have more of a history and a name, because they deliver experiences that go way beyond what you might get from the indie guys. It is OK, they have the money and the numbers behind. This is a trend that has been changing in the last years and that no longer holds true in most cases though.
In this case in particular neither of these apply. In my mind CDProject RED are already the big name, from whom I will expect unrelenting quality. Because after what they achieved they can't be considered the little guy any longer. With the Witcher 2 they delivered a game that is truly above and beyond any RPG from the last years, that feels like a product of love, careful planning and an overall shout to fans and the gaming community that says we know what you want

reviewText:
Don't buy Witcher. Buy Witcher 2. Need explanation? Read on.

OK, let's make something perfectly clear. I've spent at least 17 hours in Witcher and although I've recommended it in my Steam review, I don't think too fondly of that game. I've never got through it. Although the story is OK (but not great), I consider Witcher to be ''buy it on sale'' title. Game mechanics are so broken I've lost all of my will to play it. I just couldn't stand it.

Although a friend of mine (Witcher fanatic and a gaming journalist), a guy that says Skyrim can suck his balls, recommended Witcher 2 to me on more than a few occasions and although he pointed out the game is different than the first one, somehow I've managed not to get it until this last summer sale. And I didn't buy it this summer, either - this friend bought it for me as an act of protest because I've neglected an awesome game.

Did I say awesome? Yes, I DID. Witcher 2 is AWESOME. It goes straight into a Chamber of greatness which includes titles such as Doom II, Duke Nukem 3D, Quake II and Morrowind.

Witcher 2 brings an awesome and oh-so-needed upgrade to every single system of Witcher universe. The story gets really suspenful and interesting now, so great it leaves the first one in the dust. It makes it funny. Combat? ♥♥♥♥ing finally. No more mini-games click-on-time attacking that made me so nervous. This is a proper sword-wielding and cast-spelling game. Fighting numerous opponents is a joy now. You can dash and stab almost in perfect harmony; fights in Witcher 2 are soul-soothing experiences. Quest finding and resolving is easier and more logical, menus are no longer a cluttered mess, girls are more naked and dwarves curse and drink like late GG Allin.

Witcher 2 is a great, great game that shall be rewarded with a CLASSIC title as the time goes bye. Its living and breathing world will suck you in and you will choose a side. And you'll ENJOY IT.

Once again, DO NOT SPEND YOUR MONEY AND TIME ON WITCHER. Get Witcher 2 and don't let the first game keep you away from this masterpiece.

P.S. Dwarves. I love MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING DWARVES!!!

***
If you like this review, feel free to join me for some more recommendations at http://steamcommunity.com/groups/libereviews

reviewText:
*might contain minor spoilers*

Almost 5 years after the release, I finally played Witcher 2.

You play as an imprisoned witcher, Geralt of Rivia, who is accused of murdering a king. The game begins with compelling flashbacks in which you storm a castle, and it shows how the murder happened. Through the game, you are chasing the real killer as well as try to recover your memories about the Wild Hunt and Yennifer. You meet interesting characters (some from the 1st Witcher game), and in one point have to choose who will you follow. This changes the story quite a bit (mainly different location in chapter 2), so the game can be enjoyed in the 2nd replay.

The game has prologue, 3 chapters and an epilogue, with different maps you cannot return to when you finish the chapter.
I don't think you must play Witcher 1 to enjoy it (I didn't finish it for instance).

Pros and cons:
+ The game still looks very pretty.
+ Good voice acting and quality mature dialog (even non clickable npcs ramble when you run by).
+ Intriguing main story, the world is rich (although you might get lost with all the different names).
+ You can 'steal' anything and nobody will attack you.
+ You can sleep with a number of women (there's a cut scene with boobies and booties).
+ Sweet soundtrack that fits nicely.
+ Not black and white: monsters aren't necessarily bad. You also have a choice to kill or spare     some people which effects the political map of the world.
+ You can skip dialogue and cut scenes.
+ Some of the quests are very interesting...

- ...but some are classic monster slaying type. Either eradicate xxx or you fight through monsters to get to the place, find item etc.
- Walking back and forth can be a chore sometimes.
- You must meditate to drink potions.
- If you are trying to collect materials for crafting weapon/armor, the local shop will have good alternative relatively cheap, which makes crafting undervalued.

I cannot really comment about fighting difficulty as I played on easy (focused on the story), but for me, the fighting mechanics were better than in Witcher 1.
The game has a few puzzles, but I also cannot comment on difficulty as I was mostly too lazy and just googled correct sequences.

All in all, it is a great game which can be bought really cheap on sales. If you haven't played Wild Hunt yet, I think these ~40 hours into Witcher world can be well spent before throwing yourself in the latest installment of the Witcher saga.

reviewText:
Much like its predecessor, The Witcher 2's greatest strengths lie in its storytelling. The characters are deep and flawed and you feel for both the heroes and the villains, the dialogue is at times witty, at times profound, and the twisting, turning intrigue of nefarious plotting, civil war, and the corrupting influence of power is always engaging and motivating. On top of that, TW2 is a vast improvement in terms of visuals, and I dare say it remains one of the best looking games ever made.

But again, like TW1, it's flaws lie in the games technical aspects. The combat system is the most frequent target for criticism, and I must admit, when I first played the game before the balancing was patched it was the single most frustrating experience of my life. Perhaps it was the benefit of hindsight that assisted me, but my second playthrough was a breeze by comparison. In saying that, the combat remains difficult to learn and beginners are unfortunately punished for lacking the clairvoyance to know when one must save before a big battle. Generally speaking, the autosave points are placed a little more kindly than in TW1 and restarts will often only send you back to the start of a fight, but when they don't it can be an annoying experience. There's also a single poorly implimented stealth section towards the start, which again tests the commitment of newcomers. But once you understand that you can dodge-roll infinitely and you put a few points into your skills you'll find that, while not the most elegant system, it's far more interactive than that of TW1 and allows the player to become quite powerful when they get the hang of it.

Criticism aside though, I'd say that this is a must-play RPG for any fan of the genre. It streamlines a lot (if not all) of the inconvenient gameplay quirks of the first game, and continues to build on Geralt's epic story in a beautiful and detailed world. I played through both games in preparation for TW3 (come on Steam, discount the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!) and while I felt every one of my 33 hours in TW1, this game never felt like it overstayed its welcome. Ultimately I was sad to see it finish, especially as the last moment of gameplay is a wonderfully powerful emotional climax.

I recommend this game at whatever price it's sold for.

reviewText: A sequel that improves in almost every way compared to it's predecessor and paved the way for the masterpiece that is The Witcher 3. The trilogy has constantly changed to cater the needs and desires of it's fanbase, a thing most evidently found in the streamlining process of The Witcher 2 in regards to the first one in the series. The graphics in Assassins of Kings are gorgeous and demanding even after 5 years since it's release. You will need both a decent system and plenty of time to enjoy this game. It's not worth rushing through it or skipping any dialogue. In fact, I highly recommend that you play and finish The Witcher 1 first, so that you may import your very own  save file (and game choices) into Witcher 2. This save system and the choices that ultimately matter, make the series as fascinating as Mass Effect or Dragon Age. Only the best crafted RPGs care for player choices throughout several gameplays.

reviewText: This is an RPG taken to the next level. The storyline, the combat, the graphics, they're all the best I've experienced so far. You are a witcher, a mutant, a monster slayer caught in political games. The story is engaging and it consists on choices that really matter and in this game, choices really shape the course of your adventure, as act 2 is not the same(depending on who you chose to follow) and act 3 has different goals. No matter what you choose, is worth playing more than one time, since this world is a gorgeaus one to explore. Side quests are interesting as the main quests, which means that doing everything is definitetly a joy. Combat is fluid yet tactical and it has some flaws(noticeable on higher difficulties). By tactics I mean not just the way you move, but the way you prepare; there are various potions with various effects, but some just fit to make your battles easier. The characters are fascinating and you'll find yourself never skipping a dialogue. The graphics are gorgeaus but demanding; you might not pass higher than medium settings(you should check the forums on this topic). Even on lower settings, being a PC game, you'll still have a great visual experience.\nIn conclusion, this game is a tremendous RPG which is highly appreaciated by old school player and new ones alike. There's nothing not to like, since everything shines(in a new dark medieval way).\nMy score for this jewel is 9.8. May your swords be sharp on both edges!

reviewText:
This is one more of those cases like Portal where the first game felt like a real PC game and the next one feels more like a console-optimized interactive movie. (To a modest degree, but in that direction.)
Yes, the production value might be high, the story might be interesting, but I'm not reviewing a movie here, but a game.

While in the first Witcher game, I liked the style, all its strong points so much, I could easily overlook the various weak points, but in this game, from the very beginning, I saw little but its flaws.

And because I saw way too many to edit them elegantly, here is a list of notes of the things that bothered me, in no particular order:


- Dithered lighting!
- Anisotropic filtering is enforced in the nVidia driver (since the game doesn't seem to have the option), but it still runs on trilinear!)
In these two points the graphics in Witcher 2 are actually worse than in the first game.
- Almost immediately vanishing corpses. (Same in the first game, but come on! Go with the times!)
- No graphics engine or keyboard config settings in game, only via launcher. The first game had all of this.
- Some fast-mouse-click QTE (quick time event) minigames are unnecessary and kind of harm immersion (sometimes practically click now or die" - especially one scene in the prologue was annoying

reviewText:
The Witcher 2 is a sequel to CRPG's The Witcher . The game sets after the Witcher timeline (No spoilers, just in case). You play as Geralt of Rivia, a monster-for-hire. He was framed for murdering the king, so he had to clear his name somehow. It is your choice how you play and how you interact to people. Story is what this game more interesting. Once, you have made the decision, it affects the environment, also the characters as well. The atmosphere is based on Medieval structure (I think).

+ Pros + Great Story
+ Import Save file from Witcher to Witcher 2
+ Dark and violent side quests
+ Atmosphere
+ Graphics (not bad for 2011 game)
+ Story about under 50 hours (Replayability available)
+ Characters

- Cons - Combat seems to be repetitive (dodge rolls, slashes animation)
- Consuming potions by meditating
- Skill trees
- Slight steep curve on controls
- Messy User Interface (UI)
- Crafting seems to be dodgy (because of picking up sums of any particular ingredients)

This game is recommended if you are insist to play the game. It is enjoyable game but the combat seems to be mashing clicks and space button to dodge. I forgot to mention how messy the game's UI is. Overall, it's a great game to play.

reviewText:
I bought this game for $2.50 and all I can say is, wow. After purchasing the first and second games for the price of a chocolate milk, I have spent over 85 hours on the games. I really enjoyed the first one, then when I played this it blew my expectations out of the water. The story, the characters, the settings, but most of all the highly improved sword and fighting mechanics. I finally felt in control of Geralt.

This game was smooth and well polished at the time of playing. Although some of the game seemed quite easy, it regularly proved to be difficult in others requiring you to think about your steps. Not challenging enough to make you give up, but enough to really involve you in the battle. Yet, this is where my one complain of the game comes up. You cannot consume any of your alchemy items or oil your blade once the fight has started. A lot of the time you may not know who you are going to fight or when. Since all consumables are timed, you don't want to always use them up. This meant sometimes saving your game, running around, loading back to the previous save to know what you should consume. I hope in the 3rd title this is changed back.

Over all, amazing game. Will play through again since the story can go 2 ways. I want to see both paths that Geralt takes and am really looking forward to playing through again.

Also want to see how many boobies I can convince women to show me since so far it's 100% more in this game than real life.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game and this is why:

Storyline:
The storyline is packed with distrust, politics and personal agendas which I found very interesting. Every character had their own ambitions, attitudes and reason for their actions. I found that I either liked or was undecided about a character, with a few characters that I hated. The storyline flowed well and almost every side quest made sense given the situation that the character was in. You even had some sidequests were you had to track creatures nest and blow them up which was fun and a different version to the usual kill x collect x formula . You were able to make multiple choses in the game and almost every chose matter towards either the main storyline or a sidequest and possibly both. Many of the choses that you choose from had its positive and negatives. You rarely got an option that seemed like the best option but more like 3 or 4 options that could be good but also could be bad. I like this and made me think of what option I should choose. Some warning there is a lot of dialogue about the political issues of Geralt's world and they do shoot out a lot of names which may push some people away. But if your intrigued about  political struggles, regicide, betrayal, mystery and even some romance then you will love this storyline.

Gameplay:
Utterly love the gameplay. It is an action rpg with a skill tree, some what, similar to diablo or other action rpgs. But the overall gameplay is different then your typical action rpg where you kill a huge mobs of monster one right after the other. In this game you do more exploring around and talking to people than killing creatures. But when you do kill creatures they are incredibly dynamic battles were you have options on how you want to kill your foe. Do you want to ensare the creature in a trap and stab it with you sword or do you want to shock it with a bomb and run in for the fatal blow. Also you do not stand their and fight the monster exchanging blows, no you try to dodge or parry the blows so you don't get killed because you can be overwhelmed in the game pretty easily if your not careful. Oh but dont forget your potions. There is an alchemy system where you can make potions using herbs that you find in abundance in the wild as well as oils and poisons that can be added to your weapon for a short period of time. These potions will increase your stats, or allow you to see in the dark, some even give you advantages at a cost of another stat being reduced. These potions are extremely helpful and usually only last around 5 to 10 minutes unless you have some points in the alchemy skill tree. Potions can only be used before a battle starts and you have a limit on how many potions you can drink. So I enjoyed thinking about what potions I should use and when I should use them. You are also capable of creating bombs, traps, armor and weapons which I have seen before, but still adds something to the game, especially the bombs and traps.

Graphics:
The graphics is just amazing for its time and I was suprised at the differences between the looks of some characters that were from the first Witcher game. I also liked how original the creatures looked  in comparison to many other games I have played. This difference added to the dark tone of the game quite well. The graphics made exploring around a lot more enjoyable overall.

Replayability:
There is some good replay value to this game. There are several different difficulty levels that you can play on, and the storyline branches out in two different ways. Therefore, you will have to play the game again to see the other part of the storyline that you missed the first time. There are also differences in sidequests depending on which storyline branch you choose as well as different results to the side quests depending on your choices.

Cons:

Yes, like all games there are some cons to this game. The big one is... the map. It might just be me but I found the map to be utterly confusing to understand.  Some things on the map that looked like walls ended up not being walls and other parts of the map that didn't look like walls ended up being walls. I was playing on the controller and there seemed to be no shortcut button to see the bigger version of the map, you had to open up the selection menu and press map every single time which got on my nerves a bit. Another con to this game is the game's inability to work properly. Sometimes the game would either slow down making gameplay difficult or just crash. Also this issue could very much be an issue with my computer and not the game. Another issue I had with the game was although the towns were well thought out and dynamic the same people walking around kept saying the exact same two or three lines every single time you would pass by them, unless you were having a conversation with them. Next time I hope that the people have atleast a few more lines that they could say.

So overall, this is a great game that you should play to get prepared for Witcher 3, which looks amazing.

reviewText:
Awhile ago I made a Witcher 1 review, and although I enjoyed it I felt  it had some annoying bits which unfortunately lessened the experience.
In The Witcher 2, nearly anything I harped on before was fixed.

The combat is much improved, especially with the Combat Rebalance Mod. (if it's your first playthrough use vanilla combat first)

The story is awesome, although I feel the first one had more of an impact. It starts right after the first one but it gives enough info to still get the general gist of the story. I still highly recommend you do so you won't get lost.

The graphics are amazing. It's really jaw-dropping once when you realize that it came out in the same year as Skyrim. It's simply stunning. Ubersampling is nice as it makes the obvious aliasing disappear, but it taxes even my GTX 970. You may prefer turning it off completely and dealing with the aliasing or using SweetFX.

The music was less memorable to me than the first one. There wasn't anything I really particularly liked, but in general it's okay.

The content in this game is huge. I've played it twice as much as I have the first game. Without spoiling anything, you have to make an extremely important choice at a certain point which changes the game so much it's as if it's completely new.

While there's still no jumping, and some invisible walls, they never irritated me in my playthrough. The maps are so large and the motion of climbing and descending cliffs are fluid.

Signs and potions were a much bigger deal in this game than the last. I played it on normal difficulty, and while not as hard as Dark Souls, without a proper strategy and using brewing potions you're going to die...very easily.

However one rather major con is that the skill tree alchemy is useless. There's a limit to the number of skill points you get, and you'd much rather spend them on tangible things that affect your overall combat skills, not potions. Similarly, I probably used only one mutagen in the whole game.

There's a wide range of weapons and armor in the game, so you won't really need to buy from merchants. You'll likely want to craft them yourself, or find good ones through quests and loot.

Also this is personal preference but I found a gamepad to be better than KB+M, ignoring the inventory which is good with a KB+M, but annoying with a controller. I'd constantly unequip my boots when using one and found it really hard to manage my stuff. I still enjoy using a KB+M, although I think I prefer a controller with this game.


It's an extremely solid game that any RPG fan should at least try. The environment is vast so you won't feel restricted or as if you're going down a corridor. The combat is good, not Dark Souls level but not Skyrim level either. It's also far better with  the free Combat Rebalance mod. Story is excellent as expected.

Although I feel like it's an amazing game, I just don't think it reaches a generally perfect 10/10 but instead an excellent 9/10. Replayability is low for those who don't like seeing the same story again and combat can be tedious and downright frustrating at times (Not to mention targeting sucks).You'll want to save often as dying can send you way far back but too many saves causes frequent crashing. (I recommend disabling Steam Cloud) There's no way to move quicker, no sprinting or mounts. There's rolling, but it can't be done in areas like towns where they don't want your sword out. I also think the general atmosphere in the Witcher 1 was better, it had a darker and more serious tone although quite bleak. It seems The Witcher 3 is going to adopt a far more brighter tone, which is a tiny bit of a shame.

EDIT 1: After looking at Witcher 3 gameplay, it's obvious that CD Projekt Red downgraded their graphics. At the very least, they did not deliver on the advertised game shown for 35 minutes back in 2014. This is a bit disappointing, I even remember in my first Witcher 1 review I said, Oh
date: CD Projekt Red don't downgrade for consoles! They aren't like Ubisoft!" Originally the Witcher 3 was going to be a preorder
recommended: but now it's something I'll pick up a little later when I have time.\n\nEDIT 2: Looks like the Witcher 3 is an excellent game! Rejoice! Still miss the old graphics though
hoursPlayed: but at least CDPR admitted the downgrade."

reviewText:
Definitely one of my most favorite games of all time and the best RPG EVER. In The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings you play as Geralt of Rivia, a legendary Witcher, based on the novels of Andrzej Sapkowski. Witchers are monster slayers for hire, with their mutated bodies and skills they wipe out monsters for a pay. But in this saga Geralt tries to regain his memory which he lost when fighting the Wild Hunt. (Read novels or play TW1/2 to know more about the story) on his way he has to deal with choices that have influence on your progess in the game.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

PROS

+ Beautiful breathtaking graphics
+ Epic long and interesting story
+ Non-linear gameplay
+ EXTREMELY immersive atmosphere
+ Choices are important, in the game you always have the possibility to make choices you like and they all have their different consequences.
+ Awesome soundtrack
+ Interesting sidequests, unlike other RPGs or games these sidequests will totally not get you bored.
+ Great and original characters
+ Possibility to lay traps and hunt
+ Different Monsters are spread throughout every location
+ You are able to explore caves, areas, forests, etc
+ Dynamic combat, dodging and attacking on the right time is VERY important.
+ Alchemy, you can craft potions and enhance your weapons in order to prepare for a battle.
+ Really nice boss battles
+ Skill tree that has 4 different ways with useful abilities, Training, Swordmanship, Magic, Alchemy
+ Huge arsenal of weapons, magic light armor to heavy, obtainable through sidequests, lootable chests, barrels, etc throughout the whole world, even forgeable with the right materials and diagrams!
+ Steam trading cards

CONS

This game totally has NO cons at all. I will just state some stuff that might be a con to other people. But in my opinion this game is way too perfect to have cons.

- It really seems complicated in the beginning but you'll get used to it, dont give up to fast. (You'll understand what I mean if you play the game for the first time)
- The combat system is not like your average RPG game, it has special and dynamic mechanics. Every enemy has a different pattern and the way you approach it is very important. Dont start rushing to kill your enemy, block and dodge till you learn how he moves and attacks. And maybe which magic is fatal to him. Even when playing it at easy mode you will struggle at a certain moment. Even I, myself, had died a couple of times at a boss battle because of not being serious and not knowing his pattern and style.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I double-recommend you this game, you'll totally fall in love with it. TW2 is a huge improvement to TW1, you can start at TW2 since you get the storyline told of TW1. TW3 is coming in May so while you are reading this review dont hesitate to get TW2 and prepare yourself for the third saga of The Witcher after you finished this game. The atmosphere, characters, maturity, choices (Which are VERY important to a lot of people, no one likes scripted stories and wants it their own way while they progess through the game) and many other stuff makes this game so special. This game is totally a must have for RPG lovers, even if you never tried RPGs or dont like them then try this one. Its worth the money and wont disappoint you.

reviewText:
The Witcher 2 is one of the best action-RPGs around.  Well-written and mature story, plot, and dialogue.  The characters are well-developed. And, the decisions that you make throughout your journey changes the game dynamically.

The controls are fluid, intuitive, and mapped in a style that is conducive to gameplay.  For those that are curious, I played all 60 hours of gameplay with a mouse and keyboard.

Visuals are excellent for its time, and it has aged well.  Also, it is well-optimized.  My graphics and video options were set to ultra, 1200p, all maxed except for uber-sampling.  When I played The Witcher 2, I was using a GTX 670, i5-2500k.

However, The Witcher 2 focuses less on monster hunting lore, and more on the political aspect of The Witcher universe.  Even then, there is some monster hunting and ghouls to fight during your downtime before you return to the game's political intrigue.

If you are a fan of The Witcher books, The Witcher 1 videogame, and its universe, you owe it to yourself to play this game.  Maybe, even twice.

9.5 out of 10

Highly recommended

reviewText:
The witcher 2 is set in a fantasy medieval world inspired by polish and Russian mythology and based on Andrzej Sapkowski’s books. You play as Geralt of rivia, a witcher. Witchers are white haired mutants engineered to be professional monster slayers and are generally feared and looked down upon by regular people, Geralt uses two swords, a silver sword to fight monsters and a steel sword for humans. Because the game is a direct sequel the opening prologue puts you right into the action and new players to the series can get a little lost, however you don’t need to play the first game to fully understand what is going on, plus the witcher 2 has an extensive journal with all the information. The prologue starts off with Geralt imprisoned after being framed for assassinating the king during a siege, he’s being interrogated by the kings special forces and you play through his memories as he explains what happened during the siege. Later you manage to escape from the prison and your quest to clear your name and find out who’s really behind the series of assassinations begins.

The story will take you to a number of different kingdoms and cities and you’ll meet lots of very interesting characters, how different events happen during the story is based on the decisions you make, As the story goes on the plot gets deeper and deeper, and the bigger picture becomes clearer ,who will geralt save? who will he kill? who’s side will he choose? the faith of entire kingdoms can be directly or indirectly be affected by the choices you make, the line is blurred between pure good or evil and there’s no clear morality, you do what you think is best, sometimes choosing the lesser evil in the name of the greater good, The role you play in the game has a very heavy effect on the story. The game has 16 very different endings and fully completing it will take you around 40 hours. Also i have to mention the game and story touch on drugs, murder, torture, ♥♥♥♥, incest, racism, nudity and more, however they all fit very well into the witcher universe and make the game feel very realistic and mature. If i was to compare it to a tv series it’s like game of thrones but with a richer world and with an eastern European flavour added to it.

Gameplay wise the Witcher 2 is in third person and you fight in real time, combat is not easy, Geralt is not invincible and a group of knights could easily kill him if you’re not careful. The witcher 2 is a fantastic sequel, everything that was great about the first game has been immensely improved, the combat, the story, the characters all have been improved to a degree that is almost unbelievable, graphically it is one the best looking games ever made. The game is truly a masterpiece with a rich and detailed world, good gameplay and a deep and interesting story.

reviewText: Pinning down precisely what makes the world of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings so enthralling took me some time. It's not that the fiction is particularly mature
date:
though that's undoubtedly a term that will be tossed around until the next hyper-gritty fantasy game pops up. Think about it for a second: The Witcher, Geralt of Rivia, is a crag-faced, cat-eyed, gravelly-voiced mutant hardass who only stops screwing and fighting when occasion calls for a philosopher, at which point he dutifully duels scholars and monarchs with a tongue as sharp as either of his two swords. He is a character straight out of a 15-year-old boy's misused English notebook; the wounded warrior poet who, by the way, gets all the consequence-free sex he can handle, since he's totally shooting blanks, bro. And sure, he's stoic -- but he's also got a sensitive soul somewhere beneath that scar-laden chest of his, damn it.

No, what makes the Witcher's world so absorbing is an amazingly cohesive and consistent visual vocabulary that is -- and I know this is going to sound ridiculous -- far more logical than is typical for fantasy games. The impoverished fishermen of the riverside village of Flotsam shuffle around in nothing but ruddy underwear. Dumpy town guards patrol in filthy rags that still bear their national colors. Ornate attire is (for once) consigned solely to the upper class. Buildings look planted and properly dilapidated. This may seem a small thing, but from the first minutes of the game, it's clear how much effort has gone into researching how a society like the one portrayed would look; this medieval civilization, infused with -- but not dominated by -- magic and mystery (props to developer CD Projekt), is just awesome.

Similarly impressive: the degree to which the story changes based on your actions. Game makers (and publishers, and shareholders, and preview writers) love to crow on about choices and consequences. Hell, if you buy the PR spin, every single BioWare game in the past decade has been a watershed moment for cause and effect in video game storytelling. But frankly, the lofty language usually leads to a letdown -- the best we usually get are mundane tics on a morality slider that may or may not unlock a new dialogue tree, or perhaps a new companion somewhere down the road. I'd go so far as to argue that the only stable of games that's been quietly, consistently offering a serious set of genuinely game-altering forks-in-the-road for nearly a decade now is Acquire's Way of the Samurai series.

Not anymore.

While we have the underlying storyline of murder, intrigue, and (more stupidly) amnesia to which The Witcher 2 continually returns, the minutiae is wholly malleable. The allies Geralt makes on his journey and the enemies he combats shift with your mood swings; larger decision points alter the landscape of the world dramatically, but even minor events can cause repercussions much later in the game -- and how the whole thing ends is entirely your choice. Reading after-action reports from fellow players is like a game unto itself. Nobody seems to experience quite the same scenarios.

Not all is well in the Pontar Valley, however. Combat, for instance, is a serious problem made even worse by a poorly implemented, obscenely difficult and unhelpful opening segment. Plow into battle unprepared, and you might as well expect the worst: Even on moderate difficulty levels, this is not a game in which potential sources of aid can be ignored. Traps, bombs, magic, daggers, pre-battle potions... every tool in Geralt's arsenal is an absolute necessity.

Once I got the basics down, the extremely acrobatic, constantly active feint-and-parry style of Witcher warfare became seriously enjoyable -- just don't expect the prologue section to teach you much of anything valuable. And even when I finally felt like a proper monster-hunting mutant badass, I occasionally came across the rare room or fight so absurd that I had to wonder if CD Projekt understood the limitations of its own combat system. Geralt in a room too cramped to allow for falling back and trap placement? Battles before which you have no time to meditate and drink potions? No thanks.

Worse still, the user interface only exacerbates the combat system's flaws by forcing the player to keep an eye on everything but the melee itself. Geralt's vigor (read: mana) meter, health meter, buff/debuff indicators, and equipped spells/items are all scattered across the screen, which is a serious drawback when you're surrounded by screeching harpies.

But not even a terrible introductory sequence can take away from what is otherwise a fantastic game. Sure, the story is goofy, and at times the fighting is offensively clunky. The world isn't as colossal as the first Witcher's, and the ending is a bit of a tease. But in a time when I rarely bother to finish single-player games, I'm happy (and slightly embarrassed) to say that I'm already several hours into a second playthrough of Assassins of Kings. And I can't think of a better compliment than that.

Pros:
Engrossing world
story has more branches than a sycamore
technically astonishing
great voice acting.
Cons:
Combat takes getting used to and never becomes fantastic
pacing problems
too many quick-time events.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition
Original Release: 2011
Genre Tags: RPG; Mature; Adventure; Fantasy; Choices Matter
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 30-70 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWThe Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition provides a great experience, and tells a captivating tale... although it has a somewhat bland and frustrating combat system.  The game boasts a myriad of mature themes and storylines, and it is very enjoyable for those who appreciate impactful decision-making in their games.  However, the sheer magnitude of the game may cause it to drag a bit for completionists.

This game is absolutely beautiful.  The story is deep, rich, complex and mature.  The world feels immersive and lived in.  There are sufficient RPG elements (crafting, items, leveling, spells) to appease any fan.

In order to experience everything in the branching storyline, you will need to play through it a few times… or at least play through sections of the game a few times to see the results of different decisions.

The combat is probably the weak point of the game, as it is pretty bland and on higher difficulties can be frustrating.  You may want to consider playing on a low difficulty to just enjoy the story and avoid frustration.

If you can afford both the time and the money, I suggest you play the first one through at least once before playing this.  Or at the very least read a synopsis of the plot of the first game.

There are dozens of aspects I could go into detail describing when it comes to The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition, but it doesn’t seem necessary.  If you are a fan of epic RPGs with dark, immersive stories and captivating atmospheres then you will most likely enjoy this.  If you are someone who has trouble getting invested in story-driven, slow-paced experiences, then you may want to look elsewhere for your next game.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
This review will not be kind, and I will be covering nothing but its flaws. If you're looking for someone to sing The Witcher 2's praises, there is nothing for you here. Just downvote me and move on.

After spending 31 hours playing this game, I am finding it extremely hard to understand why this game and the developers (CDPR) are seen as some sort of hallowed, sanctified version of perfection and PC development done right. CDPR (and this game specifically) are brought up as a shining beacon almost every time there is a discussion about other devs making stupid decisions (whether it's QTEs in Tomb Raider, or devs not optimizing for the PC platform, etc), and I honestly could not tell you why.

I really tried to like this game. I REALLY did. I played the vanilla version, and when I found the combat to be impossibly clunky and frustrating, I downloaded the Full Combat Rebalance mod, which definitely fixed the combat but unfortunately didn't fix any of the rest of the clunky, frustrating base game.

-The texture work is distractingly disjointed (with awesome high-res textures right next to disgustingly cheap ones). Overall the game looks good, but why put hours and hours into an awesomely-done texture, and then stick it next to an asset ripped from Mario Kart 64?
-The dialog is well-acted but was recorded at seemingly random volumes. Two characters talking calmly when all of a sudden one of them is talking REALLY REALLY LOUDLY, BUT STILL IN A NORMAL VOICE. It is beyond weird, and ridiculously lazy/shoddy.
-The story is political intrigue by everyone towards everyone, secretly involving everyone. It gets UNBELIEVABLY tiresome, and you stop being surprised by it halfway through. Twists stop being interesting when that's all there is.
-Dialog-based intimidation and charm are always successful (at least for me) so there's really no reason for them to even be there.
-EVERYTHING is pre-scripted. fist-fights are QTEs, story battles that are supposed to be time-based will continue until you kill X number of enemies, and even WALKING THROUGH A DOOR is a scripted event. No loading screen, just stand in front of door and press X, Geralt centers himself against the door, opens it and goes through, and closes it behind him. Repeat for EVERY character! If you have a group of 5 guys, each individual one centers themselves, opens, walks through, and closes. Unimportant, sure, but it is SO HIDEOUSLY STUPID, and would be SO easy to fix.
-Story fights that need to be repeated over and over and overandoverandoverandover.
-Speaking of fights: Combat ends up being a slash or two and a sign or two, followed by 27 rolls around the arena while your signs recharge and the enemies un-bunch. Repeat for 40 minutes.
-You cannot walk freely. You can't jump, and can only climb in pre-ordained places. You can only jump down in pre-ordained places. The whole thing is SUPER stuffy, and this game does NOT deserve to be called open-world" at all.

Ugh

reviewText:
The Witcher 2 is one of those rare games in which you do not predict what is going to happen, one of those amazing games that, if you make the wrong decision, you will face the consequences. The thing that makes this so good is that not everything is clear, it is not black and white/paragon and renegade actions.

Of my current hours (37.7), I have played within the span of 3 days. It is an addictive and excrutiatingly hard game(on dark difficulty, which I decided to start on) and while the learning curve is quite steep for begginers, it's well worth it.

Alas there are a few cons to every masterpiece, for example, very little carry over from the first Witcher game (coming from a Mass Effect background) and was quite dissapointing that there were very few references to Alvin or any of the major decisions you made (eg. The scoia'tael beating on your ♥♥♥ even if you helped them in the first). Also, I finished the game without any need for the alchemy skill tree, and a lot of tasks such as building the Oathbreakers outfit is long and tedious.

The lack of big bossfights were a little dissapointing and for me personally, the bosses were too easy (except that damn squid).

However, the game makes up for it with breathtaking graphics (especially seeing as it is around 4 years old) and quite fluid combat, along with amazing storytelling elements and interesting plot lines. Although the lore can be boring for some and confusing for others at times as the game attempts to keep you in the dark on various matters.

All in all, fantastic game.

reviewText: This definitely is Game of the Year 2011. The single best RPG I have played since Planescape: Torment. The characters are deep and complex, the storyline develops depending on your actions and choices. It takes what was good from every single RPG released in the last 15 years and makes it into something better. The graphics are simply the best ever seen in an RPG to date, if not the best that we have so far in any game (compare to Crysis if you want to). The flaws are few if any. The stealth sections are not the best, but they are optional, and there are a few bugs and such. There is no ACTUAL character customization, but you can change what the protagonist is wearing with quite a bit.\nThe combat system works quite well. It may not be the best combat system in gaming history, but it does exactly what is is supposed to do. But all that is just beside the point. reviewText:
I bought this game for $3.99, is it worth paying that. Yeah!

Some positives---
1. I like the combat with the varying swords, and steel and silver depending on your opponents. Throw in some magic and it feels balanced.  The combat is better than Witcher 1.  Witcher 1 combat; some people just got fed up with the combat system in the game and stopped playing because of it, sadly missing out on the story in 1.
2. I like the crafting, you have potions and sword oils to improve your combat and health perks.
3. The story line is good, it flows and it keeps it's reference to Witcher 1.
4. The characters are rich with personality! Each character has their own personality.  Elves, Dwarfs, humans, mutants,  monsters have their own environments, attitudes.
5. Dialog choices are pretty clear, and there are two paths you can take in the game.  It isn't entirely clear whether you are going good, evil or more evil through the game though. However the 2 paths effectively give you 2 different playthroughs, with some side missions available on one path and slight different missions on the other path.
6. The environments are unique and atmospheric, and feels large enough for the game.
7. It has Steam Achivements, and for me they are like an added guide to things and directions to take in the game that I might not have otherwise discovered on my own. (there are secret achievements as well)
8. Merchants are great, they vary on what each sells.  However make sure you don't accidently sell the wrong thing or the buy back will be expensive (save often in case of mistakes)
9. There is a primary storage location so you don't have to carry all your crap around, and it is maintained in each town as you progress through the chapters.
10. Will I play it through a second time to experience the other story path? Yes!

Some negatives---
1. Sometimes the combat for magic is delayed even when mashing it... which causes you to die.  I did a lot of cursing! Read on a forum where one guy said to disable the enhanced features, so I did but it didn't fix it.  Maybe it's a keyboard thing? All I know is I wasn't the only one who experienced it.  And I've got a custom high end machine, and my keyboard is a G11 gaming keyboard.  Regardless the magic works on time sometimes, but not instantly another time. (it's also noted as a bug on some of the forums)
2. The potion creating system can get tedious and a bit over drawn out, even picking up plants gets annoying with having to click mouse, then move mouse to yeah pick it up and then click again.  It'd be better if it was quick like ES:IV Oblivion, picking up and creating.
3. No fast travel.. and I would like fast travel (I've read where people say you don't need fast travel because the environments are small enough).  Here's 2 reasons I feel it could use fast travel... 1) the running is like a jog and would be nice if it was faster so give me a sprint option!  I even searched for a way to increase run speed (like you can for FO New Vegas in the console) but couldn't find a way to increase it though.  2) the second reason I'd like fast travel is the map pretty much sucks a$$! If you don't believe me then watch this video another guy created! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bunzBQdB9EI&feature=colike
4. The map sucks!!! Hire a cartographer for the mapping system, someone who understands the importance of elevations in maps! LOL  Refer to YouTube link above! When you get deep into the game, yep you'll likely start yelling like this guy does in the video listed above. I had to keep going to YouTube/Google to find certain locations... it was really annoying! And when you don't run really fast and you wind up on the other side of town and want to see if the mission is the other way you have to keep going back and forth and back and forth it's annoying! Again a sprint or fast travel would have helped! Luckily in the second playthrough having already found the locations it should be less of a headache to find places.. if I remember where they are.. LOL
5. The nudity is tacky, plain and simple! LOL  Seriously the make out session with Geralt and Ves, Ves is completely naked makin' like she's banging him but Geralt still has his pants and boots on!? LOL It's a double standard plain and simple, saying it's okay to exploit women but not men. If they are going to have gratuitous sex, that will only appeal to guys who can't get laid in real life then at least make it something like they had in Dragon Age Origins.  I could do without the women are all sl_ts attitude, minus the mages who are apparently b*tches and can't be trusted in this game.
6. Lastly the Quick Load could use an improvement to the programming and insert an algorithm to speed load times, so it looks for the last created quick save to load instead of reading oldest to newest file then load.  If you save a lot then later in the game your huge save folder will slow load time.  I'm a chronic saver, due to my need to explore dialog options and I accumulated 2 gig of saves in one playthrough. The slow loading can be avoided/fixed by moving a chunk of your oldest saves elsewhere if you find your quick load slowed.  This is a case where it was fast when you started the game but suddenly noticed the load times slowing, towards mid to end of the game.  If it was always slow to load then it's prolly your machine...

Don't let my negatives deter you from buying.  Just be aware it's not perfect! I bought it cheap so no skin off my butt! I'd like to see a Witcher 3, but with my negatives eliminated.. LOL
There are also mods here that will enhance the game: http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/top/?

reviewText:
The Witcher 2 is a game with memorable characters, beautiful towns and landscapes, and a story filled with political intrigue. It's rare to come across a game with choices which feel impactful while avoiding typical 'black and white' or 'good and evil' situations. What lacks in gameplay is made up through the narrative.

The gameplay is sub-par. Geralt of Rivia is equipped with two swords: one for human-slaying and one for monster-slaying. With magic-like abilities called signs to go along with his swordplay, Geralt is a force to be reckoned with. Dodging and parrying are two important aspects of the combat system. Geralt can die in a moment's notice if the player isn't careful, so it's vital to know when to be aggressive or defensive. However, The combat feels sluggish. The tab-targeting feels unresponsive at times, dodging does not always go the way the players want it to, and contact with enemy units does not feel responsive. A huge plus though is the way a player has to prepare for each encounter. Geralt cannot use potions during combat, only when he is meditating, which a player can do at anytime outside of combat. Potions range from boosting his recovery rates to increasing his attributes and resistances. It's a fairly comprehensive system and adds a layer often missing from other games.

To level up, the player is given a 'skill tree' to add attribute points to four different categories, each composing of their own active and passive skills: Training, Alchemy, Signs, and Swordsmanship. The leveling up system is not complicated, but the choices you make are important. Geralt can level up to 35, which for example can fill up  the Training Tree and one other. So the player is given the choice of specializing in a certain tree, or become a jack-of-all-trades, balancing their skills points across all areas. It's a simple system which relies on player choice as a main driving force.

The story is interesting enough to continue unraveling its many mysteries. Geralt meets friends, foes, and backstabbers along the way. What's great is that each character has a sensible motive to their actions. Voice-acting is great and the writing is well-done. The cutscenes do not offer much in terms of action, but the dialogue options and the strive to know more about the characters is enough to justify the more static encounters.

Visually the game is absolutely beautiful. The lighting was and still is the best in the gaming industry. It benefits to take a second and marvel at the scenery surrounding Geralt. The forest around Flotsam, the first town Geralt encounters, is stunning. It helps make the world come alive, and like Mass Effect, creates a very convincing world, as if there's a lot more going on than what Geralt sees in his eyes. The character models, although great, could use some variety. It was common to come across the same character models across various parts of the game.

If you are a fan of mature-themed RPG adventure, this game ranks among the best of them. It comes highly recommended.

Hard to not like it if a RPG fan, the world and lore is great, the plots are like an episode of Game of Thrones, and wandering the areas doing side quests is as fresh as going for walk-abouts in Skyrim.

Its more linear then other RPGs out there, esp sandbox ones like Elder Scrolls, but does well because of it, theres dozens of choices you make that do actually effect outcomes massively, the whole of ACT II is in a different area and people depending on how you end ACT I for example.

Still one of the best looking PC games out there too, get it.

reviewText:
It's a great game.  As in Witcher 1, your choices matter.  When it was released the graphics were next-gen, but it was nearly unplayable on my system due to bugs.  Here we are years later with the Enhanced edition for which I am playing it through a second time, and there are still bugs.  Nothing game breaking, but highly annoying nonetheless.

It's still a great RPG with an intriguing story, though I am betting you'd appreciate it more by reading the books, which I have not read.  Gameplay wise, it can sometimes be a little hack and slashy, but on the higher difficulties you're forced to use a bit of strategy; it differs a good bit from Witcher 1 and takes a little getting used to.

If you're an RPG fan it's not one to miss, but you really should play the games in order to know what's going on (I actually like the 1st more than the 2nd in a few ways).

reviewText:
Drawing from it's rich source material the Witcher 2, continues the tale of Geralt of Rivia as he seeks to uncover the truth behind a mysterious group of assassins who are after royal blood. Building on the amazing story which started with the first Witcher game, considered a classic by many, Witcher 2 also improves the experience of being a professional monster-slayer. The combat is challenging and realistic ( no chugging fifty potions in the middle of a fight :P ) and the visuals and voice acting are excellent, and the story as aforementioned is gripping filled with impactful choices, characters that you will grow to love and others whom you'll want to introduce to a witcher's blade.

For those who have played the Witcher 3 Wild Hunt and want to immerse yourself more in the witcher world but find the first witcher to have not aged particularly well Witcher 2 Assassins of KIngs is an excellent game detailing Geralt's adventures leading upto the events of Wild Hunt.

Overall an amazing RPG and good entry point for those who have never played a Witcher game as well as returning monster-slayers.

reviewText:
The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings is by far one of the best RPG's ever made.

I will attempt to explain the why in my review. I will cover all levels of the
game, graphics, story, combat etc.

I will start off with the story that is being told. As someone who loves a
deep immersive story and world this game is a delight. The characters are
all well voiced and feel like they have a lot invested in the world as well
as them not appearing to be cardboard cut outs just conveying the next
plot entry to the player. You have to make choices in the Witcher 2. Which
for those of you who played the first will find a bit urking if you enjoyed
taking the Witcher path (neutrality). However the stakes are greatly raised
in the sequel. The fate of the entire northern realm is being decided and
your choices as Geralt will have long term ramifications on the world.

This is the only game I have ever had to sit back, get up out of my
chair and weigh the pros and cons of my decision. I have never felt
more invested in a series than the Witcher series. It is such a believable
world, so well crafted with so much attention to detail and love it is
unmissable. The story is exciting, if it does feel over a bit too soon. In
my 2nd playthrough I played on normal, did just about everything you
could do with some additional grinding out levels etc and that took me
about 45 hours. Where as my Witcher 1 play through took me 60+.
That being said the enhanced edition of the game that I played for the
first time since the games original launch has added a lot of content
and interesting things that make the game a bit more fleshed out to
give players a bit more of a satisfying conclusion leading up to the
third game.

The graphics to be honest are still the best we have seen on the PC.
I believe that if they released a brand new game (story, combat etc)
with the existing engine everyone would still be blown away. The fact
that CD Projekt said Nah its not good enough" and created a new
engine for the Witcher 3 is insane especially by todays standard of
lazy ♥♥♥ developers copy and pastaing as many god damn games as
they can to meet their annual release schedule (♥♥♥♥ you Call of Duty
and Battlefield) is a breath of fresh air in a stagnant market. I bought
a 980 superclocked for the Witcher 3

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Review: Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings: Enhanced Edition: It's A Fun Time But....Plough The Lilies. Err, I Mean The Combat.Genre: 3rd Person Western RPG, In-Depth Conversation System with Combat.
Developed & Published by: CD Projekt RED
Platform Support: Windows, Mac, Linux and Consoles.
Business Model: Base Game
Copy purchased by myselfRead the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

Preamble and Disclosure
RPGs are a difficult genre of game to review. With their vast worlds to explore, hours of gameplay that measure into the 50s or 100s for a single run through and each experience guaranteed to be different, well, it can be challenging to say the least. Laying my cards on the table, I played The Witcher 2 at hard difficulty for one playthrough. I did another playthrough at normal difficulty but only got part way through. I believe those two campaigns have given me enough experience to create my thoughts for this review. The Witcher 2 was purchased on Steam by myself, two years ago. Yeah, it has been that long. So, without further ado, I present A Paladin’s Thoughts and Review of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings: Enhanced Edition. 3rd person RPG for Windows, Mac, Linux and Consoles.

Overall Gameplay Thoughts
One half of the game is having a lot of long conversations with multiple NPCs. Participating in said conversations allows for world building, acquiring side-quests, trading and/or participate in….distractions.  These are generally well fleshed out conversations and you can skip a lot of lore if you want. There’s also different conversation options that can influence the responses you’ll get. It’s not as black and white as say Mass Effect’s paragon/renegade system. Instead, it generally influences how diplomatically Geralt will approach a situation. You can also use signs or intimidation to influence the conversation to your liking, provided you’ve leveled them up enough. The other half of the game is looting materials & personal possessions from every house, building, cave and castle Geralt can get into. Right from under people’s very noses. It’s insane how often Geralt is able to just steal from nobles or kings. Hehe ok, the actual other half is the combat system. It’s a fast paced hack-and-slash system that tries to encourage tactical and quick thinking as well as planning ahead. While it is possible to avoid some fights, usually by choosing the right response or avoiding a quest altogether, it’s not possible to avoid the majority of it.

Story Thoughts
Many of the characters are an unlikable lot. There are very few good guys and Geralt isn’t one of them. It feels like a lot of attention was given to Geralt, Iorveth and Vernon and the rest were mostly regulated to side arcs or doomed to two-dimensionality. Despite TW2’s attempts to subvert tropes, many characters still follow many traditional tropes and stereotypes. After all, it’s kind of hard to find characters surprising when they’re given such obvious names like Dandelion, Triss Merigold or worse: Deathmold. I mean, really? Deathmold was the best name you could up with for an evil villain? Why not just have him give us an over the top laugh when we meet him? It would have been more subtle. Everyone else is pretty easy to figure out once you meet them. They rarely stray from their outward appearance and are largely predictable. There was little attempt to justify some of the heinous acts committed by evil people. They just did it because that’s what the universe expected.

The Combat System
The combat system seems to be designed for tactical and lethal swordplay. It rewards prepared Witchers and punishes mistakes and overconfidence. Getting yourself surrounded by the enemy will lead to a quick death while setting up traps and oils will result in a lot of dead enemies. It doesn’t help that Geralt is often outnumbered by enemies. So, he’ll need to use all of his kit in each encounter to survive. 1v1 fights are very rare in this game. Though I wish they hadn’t been. While every fight has different enemies and somewhat different attacks, I found that I had to deal with them all in basically the same way. With lots of dancing, rolling and quick poking into enemies when you can. Occasionally using a sign or bomb, hoping all the while that Geralt’s health doesn’t get nicked to death. It’s too repetitive to be ignored and towards the end of the game, well, it’s just a tiresome chore.

PC Settings & Port Report
The Witcher 2 still looks impressive after all these years. There’s a decent amount of variety in locations, character models, rich weapon & armor designs, flora, buildings, you get my point. The realistic style TW2 went for is consistent with nothing looking out of place. However, the cracks are beginning to show and I can’t ignore them. Texture quality is all over the place. Geralt and other main characters can have impressive looking armor or clothing. Take a glancing look at some other people though and you start to see some gnarly texture quality. Heck, there were some textures not far off the beaten path that looked incomplete, missing or bugged out entirely. They seemed to have a hard time keeping a consistent quality at any point, which can pull you out of the world. Worse still is the view-distance. Even at max settings, pop-in is a constant problem. Foliage being the worst offender of popping in right in front of you. Combined with character models sometimes being a bit old looking and I suspect this will lead to problems in the future. That’s if we ignore a number of animation glitches, visual clipping and others. I think that TW2 will start to age just as poorly as the first Witcher has in the coming years. It’s still not a bad looking experience for now, and a lot of these issues aren’t major, but it will add up over time.

Final Thoughts
If you’re up for a fantasy story with a solid adventure, political intrigue and interesting conversations, The Witcher 2 is certainly good for it. However, it comes with some major problems that are hard to ignore. Character’s are often two dimensional. The combat system is overly difficult and punishing even on Normal mode. Not to mention, the difficulty curve can swing wildly from fight-to-fight, especially if you install the combat overhaul mod. I’m finding it harder and harder to recommend story-based games with poor combat systems. I think it’s long overdue that devs pay equal attention to both the story & combat so that each are enjoyable to experience. I give this a very hesitant recommendation. It gets that for what the devs attempted. The Witcher 2 tried to go big and very nearly succeeded. Given more time for polish, I think this truly would have been a remarkable game. For now, it is what it is. Perhaps its sequel will be what The Witcher 2 couldn’t be.

reviewText:
The game's a masterpiece. It's pushing bounderies on how a sword fighting game can be handled. I haven't played another game that so well binds melee fighting with alchemy and sorcery. The three and like the legs of a tripod for successfull advancing in Witcher 2. It's also one of the hardest games out there, mistakes in battle are unforgiving and depending on what choices you make you can have 2 completely different playing experiences.

Below are some pros and cons:

Pros
+ The game is unique in many features.
+ You actually need to combine magic, alchemy and fighting to be successful.
+ Geralt is more of a brute and not such a playboy as he was in the first game.
+ The difficulty of this game is way beyond your usual RPG.
+ Water looks the best I’ve seen anywhere in games
+ Might be the most tactical swordfighting game. Bombs, signs, traps, oils, potions + the right weapon - there's so much to take into account before going to battle.
+ Complex and interesting story with memorable characters.

Cons
- Under Mac the game crashes on reload almost every time. The game crashes a lot under Windows as well but much less than under Mac.
- Mac issue: whereas the game doesn’t take that long to load, it takes ages for the load screen to come up.
- Poor optimizing of graphics. With max settings the game is an artistic masterpiece, yet it takes a great computer to run full graphics. For some reason Witcher looks a little better in Windows than in Mac.
- Looting takes time and precision.
- The game get's easier as you play, a lot easier. Also, the gaps between difficulties are extremely jumpy, going from
dying in 10 seconds to not getting a scratch.
- The city of Vergen was a navigational nightmare, a maze in it's worst form.
- There's a weird delay at the end of the sword swinging move that starts to feel painful in battles, especially when you wanna hit and dodge.

Verdict:

I highly recommend this game, it's a positive challenge and highly original. There were few things that bugged me, most of them had to do with optimization, but I'm completely ready to forgive them all for the outstanding work of art that was built.

reviewText:
Witcher 2 takes places a month after the events of witcher 1. You can import your character from witcher 1 into witcher 2. If you do import your character, there are some differences, as well as some gear that transfers from witcher 1. They have improved several aspects overall. Combat system is much more engaging and lively. Button smashing is not enough to get through. You need to explore different strategies so that you don't get swarmed with monstors. Use potions, oils and signs effectively to stay alive. Graphics are very impressive. Inventory management is changed as well. Instead of having a certain number of inventory slots, now there's a weight limit like most RPGs. From what I can understand Witcher 2 didn't have a storage option earlier but they added it into the Enhanced Edition.

In general character development is similar to that of witcher 1. You can focus on alchemy, swordsmanship, or magic (signs). Although you do have several different abilities that can be purchased. One noticable difference is that you can directly make use of mutagens harvested from monsters and use them to enhance your armor, attack, sign intensity, critical effects, vitality etc.

Kudos to CD Projekt Red for releasing the Enhanced Edition at no additional cost for those who already owned witcher 2. This is a large improvement over the original witcher 2 since it adds multiple side-quests, cut-scenes, improved graphics, storage option etc.

I believe this is the 4th time I'm playing the game. Unlike witcher 1, where you could've remained neutral and avoid game politics more or less, Geralt finds himself being dragged into politics. There's no avoiding it in this game. There are two main paths you can follow and each offers very different quests and it makes the game playable several times without feeling repetitive. Similar to witcher 1, there is no absolute evil nor absolute good. There are no right or wrong choices. Only the consequences of your choices. The story is fantastic and excellent voice acting.

The game is divided into 3 chapters, other than the prologue and the epilogue. You have to make the biggest choice you're going to make in this game at the end of chapter 1. Thus the chapters 2 and 3 are completely different depending on your choice. You also have to make several other choices along the way which affects the story more or less. If you played witcher 1 (and you should), you would understand the situation much better. But at the same time, it's not necessary to enjoy this game as it offers an excellent story itself.

Bottom line is that this game is a must have for RPG fans. It is a huge improvement from witcher 1, which was an excellent game. So that is saying a lot. Looking forward to witcher 3 next February!

reviewText:
The Witcher series turned out to be one of my gaming diamond. It's not about graphics, but strong plot and solid RPG elements will stick with you in every moments of the game. The Witcher 2 still remain its standard of story (some parts are modified from The Witcher novel). You might want to catch up from The Witcher 1 to gain full experience of the story. The highlight is various decisions along three main chapters which point you out and force you to deal with consequence. This give high replayability like The Witcher 1.
The combat system is changed from point-and-click (The Witcher 1) to dynamic hit-and dodge (The Witcher 2). For me, the combat is greatly flexible, but less complexity in strategy (The Witcher 1 gives your more different sword styles and Sign charge). The skill system is quite stricted than The Witcher 1 skill pattern). However,  the game provides you a lot of armors and weapons choice (Yeah, you can hit boss with a scoop).
QTE is also another factor that's shouldn't be in RPG game, I feel kinda disappointed they put QTE in the end of boss fight and fistfight minigame. Cause the game lacks some challenges.
I may complain too much about its problem. However, it's just minor issues and I understand it's hard to keep its previous standard if you attempt to change something. The Witcher 2 still one of my strong RPG game all the time. even it's not deepest, longest, or toughest, but I feels very very enjoyable in every moment of this game and I have high hope for The Witcher 3.
