reviewText:
TLDR: If you tried to like the original The Witcher, but failed like I did, get The Witcher 2. If you liked the original The Witcher, definitely get this one.

I found the original The Witcher an intriguing but very confusing mess of a game. Even with the release of the Eanhanced Edition of the original I could not get into it because nothing in the game made eny sense to me.

Enter The Witcher 2 (:Assassins and all that stuff I'm too lazy to type out each time). Here is a game that throws you into the deep end of a non-conventional RPG mechanic, as well as a lore-rich story that will most likely be very unfamiliar and quite foreign to most players. And yet the game presents itself in a way that draws you into the story and lore, and teaches you just enough about its game mechanics to get you confortably started, but lets out enough detail to make you feel like you're getting better at it as you start to fine-tune your approach to the game.

Even though the story and lore can be seen as very standard fare fantasy at a glance, I advise any player to take the time to read up in the Journal to learn more about the characters, events, locations and monsters. You'll quickly see that this is not just another Middle-Earth clone, and the quality of the lore leans much more heavily towards the Game of Thrones class of fantasy world. People are driven my human desires, and no-one in the game is an idealistic representation of virute. In this world, no-one is perfect.

Then you get to the gameplay anr RPG mechanics. Yes, you have skill trees you advance through to earn new and better skills and abilities. But the game leans heavilty toward strategic planning for each fight you're going to face. Drink potions and apply temporary enhancements to your equipment to give you the edge you'll need to survive. You're not playing a standard RPG here where your character is basically a demi-god able to wade through armies of enemy troops at a whim. You may be a mutant bred for slaying monsters, but you're still very much human, and very much mortal, so you better put some thought into what the world is going to throw at you so that you can meet it prepared.

When combat erupts, things hardly go exactly according to plan though, which forces you to improvise within the general planning you had laid down. You have a wide selection of Signs (spells) and items at your disposal to help keep the odds in your favour. Drop  some traps during a fight to snare up your enemies, trow bombs to stun and damage as you hack away, and even use mind control to tun an enemy against his mates and tip the scales.

One of the things I found hardest to comprehent in the original The Witcher was the combat system. I can beilieve that it was a brilliant system, but I just never felt comfortable with it. In The Witcher 2, the combat is redone completely, feels much more action-packed and impressive than the original.

The game also forces you to go through certain choices that influence the game as you progress. And unlike other morality-based" games
date: there is never a clear-cut definition of which choice is the "good" and which is the "bad". You need to make up your own mind

reviewText: I was a big fan of the first one, despite it seeming a little old school. This game feels a little shorter, but a little better paced, especially if trying to be a completionist. I have unlocked every achievement on this game and there is no sweeter feeling than earning Madman! The way the story unfolds gives this game just as much if not more replay value than its predecessor and should prompt anyone to be excited for the upcoming third installment! This is a great game in a great series!

reviewText:
Now I sit here with the Witcher 2 finally finished.

I am not a big fan of it's combat but then I am spoiled with the Dark Souls series.

The game although bring a lot to the table. Anyone playing Crusader Kings 2 will feel like they are playing a minor hero character in a big world of politics and schemes. It is brutal world, a beautiful, brutal world! The story continues from the first game and puts Geralt in a messy messy time full of troubles. This game was released same year as Dragon Age 2 and Skyrim. It is probably not as big and as long as these two but I think it out perform Dragon Age 2 with flavour and story, I care more for the characters in Witcher 2 than those in Dragon Age 2. In Dragon Age 2 I wanted to kill them. In Skyrim I did not care even that much about NPCs and many places felt very empty. The Witcher is a very gorgeous game.

As I said before the combat is not my favourite but I can see if people prefer this over the more unique Witcher 1 combat system. The sound is good and the voice actors are in my opinion very good. The models also come in more flavours this time compared to Witcher 1. It feels a bit shorter than Witcher 1 but comes with a big replayability with the a split in the road. I do hope that all your options, Kill A, Let A go, Save X over Z, Help Nr 1 and fight Nr 2. I hope these options have consquences in Witcher 3.

The game is not perfect but to consider what a failure the big guys at Bioware itself released this year and how they continued to release overrated games with plenty of flaws, it is hard then to judge this Polish studios struggles. It is a excellent  game in a grim world! Showing the darkness of humanity and the chaos errupting from a dead king. Resembling the chaos in Europe in the middle ages in a bit. It is a grim bloody world, full of prejudice, hate, treachery and  destruction. But also lot of comeraderie, courage and love shown. 9 out of 10.

Trigger Warning: It is not a game for you SJW wimps! Go play Dragon Age Inquisition with you.

reviewText:
Played it in late 2015 with Windows 8.1. I did not play Witcher 1 previously.

This game has its flaws. It is not perfect. Among the bad things, we have:

- Several Crashes. In my 35 gameplay hours, it crashed like 4-6 times.
- Awful UX. I didn't like the menus. For instance, when buying a new weapon, you don't have the option to compare the new weapon and your actual weapon. You have to exit vendor's menu, enter your inventory, memorize your weapon, and then enter vendor's menu and compare both weapons. Awful.
- The combat is a little rough.

Among the good things:

+ The story is great. I really liked the story and the plot twists.
+ Your choices matter.  There are several endings based on your decisions.
+ The bosses are incredibly hard yet fun. I cursed at the screen several times, yet I couldn't stop playing.
+ Graphics are nice even as today.
+ Playing Witcher 1 previously is not a requirement.

reviewText:
Some my Pros/Cons

Pros:

+ Mod support
+ Ritch storyline
+ Nice looking visuals even on low settings
+ Perfect soundtracks
+ A lot of craftable items
+ High quality NPC voice acting
+ Fun during monster hunt (preparing traps/poisons/reading up on the creatures etc)

Cons:

- Unrealistic sword combat. It doesn't feel right.
- Unbalanced gameplay mechanics - Oils and potions barely last long enough to be of any use, and forcing you to drink them in meditation mode is tiresome. Also fairly unrealistic and breaks immersion somewhat. Many skills over/underpowered (i.e. dodge-roll, shield sign, alchemy tree etc.)
-Clunky UI and menus. Bad sorting options, unintuitive selection design (i.e. hover over recipe with mouse cursor, then press space or enter to complete recipe. but don't click and make sure not to move your mouse away from recipe in list). The map, while looking totally freaking awesome, is almost entirely useless. Many more problems with UI.
-Lack of camera controls and options.
-Unclear or non-existent tutorials.
-Also, doors. OMG DOORS. Another obvious piece of the game programmed with the fortcoming console port in mind.

Overall. 6/10.  I can recommend Witcher 2 if you are keen on fantasy setting and magic items crafting...

reviewText:
The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings

Pros:

. Well written, easy to follow story

. A lot of choices which are divided into 'Major' and 'Minor', the major will affect the story and the minor will usually be something personal to Geralt, such as a choice between Orens (the games currency) or some gear

. All of the main characters are fantastic, and even then, the more minor characters will have some short story behind them

. Very good graphics which still hold up today

. Good combat for the most part, knowledge is key in this game, if go into some fights without correctly preparing with oils and potions et cetera, you're probably going to die very fast

. A good 'rewardingly difficult' system similar to Dark Souls (although not as hard)

. Fairly good replayabilty

. Good game length for the price


Cons

. Game is pretty unoptimized, I bought this on my old pc, which was bad but still above the recommended requirements and couldn't this game at a stable frame rate at all. Now, however with my 390, the framerate dips from the usual 60 (on ultra) all the way down to 20 in certain situations

. The game is quite buggy, such as the game not allowing you to do simple things like climb a rock which can halt your progress into the game

. The horrible targeting system the game uses for its combat, you can only target one enemy at once which can screw up entire scenarios as the target is chosen via who is at the centre of the camera, which leads to things like being unable to attack another enemy with ease


Overall

I give this game a 8.1/10 and heavily recommend it to any Witcher or RPG fan for its great narrative, characters, and gameplay, but be wary of the games bad optimisation and bugs.

reviewText: Hmm, again the Steam recommendation system provokes thought. This isn't a great game, it's a good one. It has numerous flaws. Ridiculous boss fights (thank goodness for easy mode), stupid missions with auto fail conditions (I nearly was reduced to tears by one idiotic sequence where you had to follow someone through a greyscale cave where the mission was restarted if you put one foot wrong), display and path finding glitches, and a bizarre plot that lost me some time ago. But it also has much goodness - smashing combat, once you figure out you have to roll a lot, stunning visuals, a fantastic main character and decent supporting cast, including several strong female characters - don't be deceived by the pandering to teenage boys with the top heavy character models. There is action aplenty and a reasonable amount of exploration to do, however I feel it didn't live up to it's predecessor and it does feel curiously amateurish in places. I really have no idea how this devteam is going to pull off something as ambitious as Witcher 3, but I'll certainly be playing it. Recommended? Yes, but with the caveat that the game is deeply flawed and a definite slog at times.

reviewText:
The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings (Polish: Wiedźmin 2: Zabójcy królów) is an action role-playing hack and slash video game developed by Polish studio CD Projekt RED. It is a sequel to the 2007 video game The Witcher. Like its predecessor, the game is based on The Witcher series of fantasy novels by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. The player directs the actions of Geralt of Rivia, an enhanced human called a Witcher who hunts monsters. The fantasy world in which his adventures take place owes much to Polish history and Slavic mythology.

This game is great. The story is interesting. The music fits the mood. Battle system is good and finishing moves are awesome. And there are sex scenes. This game reminds me of Berserk.

Berserk (Japanese: ベルセルク Hepburn: Beruseruku?) is a manga series written and illustrated by Kentaro Miura. Set in a medieval Europe-inspired fantasy world, the story centers on the characters of Guts, an orphaned mercenary, and Griffith, the leader of a mercenary band called the Band of the Hawk. Themes of isolation, camaraderie, and the question of whether humanity is fundamentally good or evil pervade the story, as it explores both the best and worst of human nature. Both the manga and anime are noted for their heavy violence.

Game tip: When you are on a mission always and I mean ALWAYS choose a women's side even if she is a witch, an elf or a goat girl, because...... SEX.

reviewText:
Can't really recommed this one. The graphics are ok, but nothing to write home about considering it is supposedly an 'enhanced edition'. Story and lore seem to be dense from what I can tell after roughly two hours.

Unfortunately, combat and interaction are breaking this game for me. Combat is extremely clumsy, it basically boils down to button-mashing, where at no point you have real control over your character, but rather mash buttons as fast as humanly possible and see what the game decides to do.

Combat animations are basic, very basic, you'll sometimes stun an enemy wielding a shield, and when you strike him see a cut-scene like animation where your character delivers a killing blow to an enemy that does not have a shield.

I started the game on 'hard' difficulty, and it took me about 10 minutes to discover how to exploit weaknesses in the AI to a point where I basically go through the fights either with no health loss, the other possible outcome being dying a rather cheesy death due to the no-control combat system.

If I had to describe the combat system with one word, I'm sorry to say that word would be 'garbage', it pretty much ruins an otherwise decent game.

Interaction is similary painful, there is one interaction key (left mouse), which is also one of your main fighting keys, leading to all sorts of unintentional interactions during combat, especially since the 'hot zones' for interactions are placed badly. This also inhibits game flow, you'll sometimes run towards a ledge, and then have to move around trying to find the interaction zone to actually climb it, there is no fluid 'run up to the ledge and climb it' like you'd expect.

Got this very cheap on sale, if I had bought it for full price I'd say it was wasted money.

reviewText:
Date of review : 04/03/2014
Hours Played    : 26
Replays            : 0



I have seen a lot of praise for this game especially for the PC platform on forums everywhere on the internet. And I have also seen a lot of this: CDProjeKt Red is the only AAA game industry that cares about the PC platform"

Well after playing the game this is what I have to say: The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is a console game.



Likes:

- Great Cinematics and visuals. Clever use of post-process effects. Makes the graphics look great. Character models are very detailed.

- Deep Story



Dislikes:

- Console style gameplay
recommended: the whole game\n\n- Keyboard and mouse controls are irritating. Tried the gamepad
hoursPlayed: the K+M issues were gone
voteText: but the gamepad has its own set of issues
helpfulPercent:
the same issues for which i hate the gamepad in general. Finished the game with the keyboard and mouse except used the gamepad for arm wrestling(lol double meaning there).

- You have to use a thing called as medallion to highlight pickup objects. Because it is very hard to see pickup objects manually. And that medallion thingy has got a cooldown. It's also hard to focus on pickup objects because of the player's 'running' to 'idle' state animation.

- The minimap and the map wasn't exactly helpful. There will be some objective up a hill but you will end up in a cave directly below it. And the lack of fast travel just made it more irritating. It looks like the game wants me to memorize the directions to each place.

- There will be some objectives that are right in front of you but you will have to circle around the entire town to reach that place since the player cannot jump over a fence or jump down to the floor below. This wouldn't have been a problem if it was only needed to be done once but you need to reach that same place again and again multiple times. The lack of fast travel again adds to the frustration.

- The 'charm' option in dialogues always succeeds. No point in choosing other options.

- Music is average at best. Not great use of sound either.

- I hate memorizing stuff that isn't important to me. And the magic powers that the player has are in sign language
votesHelpful:
just made it more difficult to memorize. If it was English it would have been a bit easier. There were also some sign language puzzles. Who in the world knows sign language? There was a learning curve for me in this game. I don't usually expect a learning curve in a single-player game(after playing lots of games).

- Some side missions get FAILED if you leave the area or progress the main story. I thought it was an open world RPG. Can't even finish objectives at my leisure. The game is linear for the most part.

- The game wasn't technically impressive for me. There were a lot of loading zones/streaming levels(DOORS). Everything in the distance is either mist/fogged/depth of field blurred out. Basically everything you see in the far distance is of very low quality. And AFAIK there is no zoom functionality. And the third person camera helps hiding a lot of things. And I prefer realistic looking graphics than fantasy graphics even in a fantasy world.

- Too many cutscenes. I wanted a game not a movie.

- Show off.

- Story can be overwhelming. Too many characters to keep track of

Some useful Statistics:

It's been more than 2 years since the release of Witcher 2. So some valid statistics are available. According to Steam achievements atleast 57.1% of players have started playing the game. And 13.8% of players have finished the game. That means only 24.17% players who have started playing the game have actually completed it. Ideally for a good single player game this percentage should be above 33. This probably means that most of the players either quit playing the game or got stuck somewhere indefinitely or they had better games to play or bought it just to watch the porny stuff in it and not to play the game. I hope this gives you enough reason for why this game is not recommended.

reviewText:
The Witcher 2, is my favorite game of all time. Here is why:

When you first get into this game, one of the most incredibly made cinematics bids you welcome to the world and story. I am amazed that a small company like CDPR (used to be) could possibly deliever one of the most beautiful PC titles of all time, even in 2014.

But these guys did it right. With a huge focus on story and it's characters, this game slowly opens up for a world that has so much more depth and feel to it than many other AAA open world games. This world has the advantage on being based on a great bookseries and a having a company behind it, that has the best intentions for everything that is behind it.

It can be confusing to begin with, but without a doubt fully playable, without having played the first installment of the series. The mechanics can be a little clunky, and the developers have been forced to limit the world to big explorable areas instead of making it truly open world. But it works out for this game - Simply because everything you CAN do, is so incredibly detailed and perfected in every way. The lore and story is absolutely amazing and along with a great soundtrack and mindblowing visuals, it adds up to be the very best game I've ever played.

I write this review after completing the game several times, on each difficulty and gathering all achievements. It is extremely challenging in beginning, but in this game, preperation and strategy, is highly rewarded.

This is what makes this game so different and so much better from other games:

- Choices matter. The choices you make can change the story completely. There's actually two completely seperated chapters based only one single choice in the game. It makes everything so much more interesting.

- Everything is means something. There's no generic sides quests, like you know it from Skyrim and WoW. There's a lot of content, but they are all well thought out. You won't be forced to gather resources for hours - It will make sense in the end.

- The story is so rich and incredibly well put together. Unlike many other RPGs, you don't get to costumize your character, but also means that the story becomes much more personal, mature and interesting.

- The world, based on a book franchise, that I have now read, because of my love of the game gives this game a huge advantage. The lore is deep and detailed and CDPR has truly taken care of this in the best way possibly. This game also features some of the best soundtracks I know of.

I am incredibly excited for The Witcher 3. And I believe that, to be the only game to ever beat this. That experience will show a truly open world, with a much bigger budget and therefore, far fewer limits. The simple fact, that the main story is around 50 hours long, says a lot about how important the story is in this franchise.

I would recommend anyone who want to play Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt, to begin here. It'll give you a wonderful time, and prepare you for the third installment. I like the first game as well, but I think it might be a little too outdated by now.

TL;DR: If you want to be a medieval jedi knight, you should play this game. And who doesn't want to be a medieval jedi knight? Seriously?

reviewText:
Although highly overrated, The Witcher 2 is an interesting adventure primarily due to its story.  It's light on RPG elements and doesn't come close to the dynamic storytelling or versatile gameplay of Dragon Age (it's not even any better than Jade Empire) or Neverwinter Nights 2, but is still a good game for the grey, dark-fantasy world and complex story.  It essentially includes two versions of the campaign, each should take about 30 hours to complete.

Combat is actually decent unlike the first game, though for a PC game it has some surprising similarities to console games; invisible walls everywhere, lots of important functions bound to one key, and lackluster anti-aliasing.

Regardless, The Witcher 2 is a great game for those who are new to RPGs, and is a good first step before moving onto more serious RPGs.  Mechanics are simplified and there's hardly any actual role-playing, and its scale is very small (though the linearity will bother many true RPG fans), so it shouldn't overwhelm anyone.

reviewText:
Really damn good game overall. Good graphics, a great mature story and setting, gameplay is astronomically better than Witcher 1. That being said the combat while a million times better than the game before is still lacking, but its cons are outweighed by the pros of having to use intelligent decision-making to prepare for fights which is something that is completely missing from almost all modern RPG lately.

Remember when you had to drink that potion of fire resistance so you could fight that dragon in Skyrim? Or you had to keep a stash of holy water so you could fight vampires? Me neither.

In Witcher if you do not prepare to fight monsters like a Witcher you will fail miserably, and rightly so for thats what sets apart Witchers from just really juiced up monster slayers.


The game does suffer from trying to be too cinematic, but fortunately this is only for the Prologue. Its recommended that you play Witcher 1 before playing this but you really don't need to as Witcher 1 can be a bit of a chore to play.


I would argue that the most important aspect of this game is the mature story, if you are not very into story driven gameplay then I cannot recommend this to you.

reviewText: Geralt of Rivia, aka Gwynbleidd, the White Wolf, the Butcher of Blaviken, is the son of a sorcerer and a warrior subjected to mutations and rigorous sword and sorcery training as a child. Therefore he became a monster slayer, a mercenary known as a witcher that wanders the world seeeking work. His friend, and also a bard, Dandelion recounts his adventures as ballads and poems of the most famous witcher against monster and other evils thrown against him by fate. Geralt is not a good man, as Dandelion says himself, but he tries to maintain his humanity. He does not believe in destiny but he acts as a balance while using his steel swords against human adversaries and the silver sword to slice through monsters alike. In The Witcher 2, Geralt is mistakenly confused as a Kingslayer and as so must search for the real Kingslayer to bring him to his justice. You will face many creatures and monsters, elves and dwarves, and you will have to choose who are your allies and who will feel the wrath of your blade. Geralt is always searching for his lost past and to help him, he can count on his friends the sorcerer Triss Merigold, the bard Dandelion, the dice poker addicted Zoltan, and others that might or might not help him in his endevour. A truely epic tale, that deserves all the praise it got and more to come when Geralt, once again, start wandering the lands of the Northern Kingdoms and the Nilfgaardian Empire in search for more work and blood against all kinds of monsters. After all, that's what the most famous Witcher is after, isn't it ? Maybe not.

reviewText:
The Witcher 2 is the much anticipated sequel to the original The Witcher. Featuring a brand new engine, intense combat and a returning cast of characters.

As much as I like this game there are fairly pronounced flaws if you were a player like me, who went through the original game. Everyone except Geralt got a new voice actor, and as a result everyone feels really different for some reason. Alongside that, importing your saved game from the original is very pointless. Your magical swords and unbendable armor that previously saw you through massacring armies of enemies, now has you selling it for the first new bit of equipment. Not only that but a lot of your choices simply do not carry over.

In the original game for instance Geralt could choose to romance another girl instead of Triss named Shany. Who replaced Triss from then on in the story and was just as important. You could also choose to side with the Squirrels, who start out in this game wanting to murder you despite whatever import you might have had.

Aside from this the game is perfectly flawless, your choices are very pronounced and your consequences very real. I just wish the game had a bit more perspective on where it came from and where it was going.

reviewText: The Witcher 2 is a beautifully crafted RPG that takes place in a fantasy world that could reprsent a more sinister version of common high fantasy tropes like LOTR. Unlike most games like Dragon Age 2 and Skryim, The Witcher 2 is a labor of love that respects the player as someone who can think for themselves and not rely on the game to hold their hand. The tutorial for the game is subpar at best, with the game throwing you right into the thick of it without proper preparation. Though the game is incredibly easy for someone to pick up and learn the control scheme, the real challenge comes in the first act once you arrive in Flotsam (very minor spoiler). Playing on the Normal difficulty setting is great for someone who wants to get in right away and learn as they play without dying a lot. There is a heavy emphasis on swordplay, but in order to truely dominate your opponets and emerge ready for the next fight you need to go the extra mile. Alchemy poitions are a double edged sword as you can't drink 500 of them then go into battle as a badass killing machine. Poitions in the game have severe side effects and drinking too many could kill you before the battle has even begun. One such is a poition that gives you night vision and see through walls. However, in the light you will be blinded and forced to fight in the shadows. Drinking this along with two other poitions that affect your damage can have your player fall over dead from the overload of toxins. Magic may not seem much with a few minor spells, however they allow you to keep smaller less threating enemies out of the way while you take care of the bigger target. All in all The Witcher 2 is an amazing RPG that can't be passed up if you're looking for a little more oompf in your game. With the arrival of SteamOS support there is hardly an excuse not to play it now :D

reviewText:
Great game. One of, if not the best RPG i have played. Its not as free as Skyrim or such but its beautifully made, the characters are strong characters you care about and the game is deep. At first it can be off putting, but stick at it and you will be rewarded, make potions, traps and use them.

The combat is frustrating at first, much like the first, and you will only start to get the hang of it half way through, but its great. As you progress you realise Geralt is agility based, and excells when you keep him moving and taking on the enemies without getting in the middle of them and slugging it out. Once you realise he is not a strong slugger but an agile fencer, combat all becomes a dream.

The story is complex, the decisions are also so, and though there isnt a right and wrong choice, each one has a strong repercussion. You shape the game as you play. Great fun, and at some points i was stuck for minutes trying to decide who to help or which path to take.

By the end of it you will be itching for part three, and if not, you are dont have a pulse or are a drowner...

4 Thumbs up.

reviewText:
They took everything great in the Witcher 1 (the story, the dialogues, the immersion...) and made it better by upgrading the graphics, the gameplay and the character design. I really recommend this game, and if you plan on playing the 3rd, don't hesitate to play this one too (or even the first one if you are not afraid of the difference in gameplay).
I have only sided with the Scoia'tael yet (same as in the Witcher 1 as it seemed to be the only reasonable choice to me) but I already know that I'll replay it siding with the other faction as both groups are ambiguous.

I would just recommend to take a few mods to make it more enjoyable (nexus account is free) :
http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/276/? : automatically hides the UI out of combat.
http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/697/? : Geralt is supposed to use pirouettes, not rolling on the ground, this mod just changes the animation for dodges to make it more book friendly.
http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/115/? : this one is maybe the most important as the most annoying thing in this game is that all items are way too heavy (including all ingredients for potions/bombs)

A few advices for beginners : I see people complaining about the tutorial at the beginning... it's actually because there isn't really one ; I would then recommend anyone to just check the different controls online, recommend you to use potions (always use the regenerative one), oils on your blade (they increase dramatically the damages you deal to enemies) and runes on your weapons and armors. The steel sword is for the humans and the silver one is for all kind of monsters, and if you have a doubt wether it's a monster or a human, use the silver one.

reviewText: The Witcher 2 is a vast improvement over its predecessor, and, as the franchise is known for, has many new and variable tropes for a Fantasy RPG game. To highlight some of the game's best features, The Witcher 2's combat is reminiscent of Batman: Arkham Asylum, but requires far greater skill and preparation. I'm not new to Action-RPG's by any means, but I found the first half of the game very challenging and new to grasp, which is a good thing. The combat is by far the most enjoyable, compelling, intense, and straight forward experience I've had in a while, and for the first time, the magic, enchanting, and alchemy systems aren't overly convaluted.\n\nThe story of The Witcher 2 is dark and riviting, and is filled with lots of mystery, political strife, and several player-driven decisions during major events. The only complaint is that the game takes too fondly to the objectification of most, if not all, of it's female characters. I won't get into detail, but if you're ok with that, then I highly recommend playing The Witcher 2 for a new Action-Adventure-RPG experience.

reviewText:
Geralt of Rivia has returned, and with warm welcome. The Witcher series is becoming one of my favorites within my list of fictional sagas, and this game certainly delivers on all fronts.

Assassins of Kings pulls no punches. It starts off with an incredibly beautiful CGI introduction that rivals even the best studios. Once you start the game, you're thrown right into war, and the rollercoaster ride hasn't even reached the first hill at this point. Geralt's adventures are plentiful - every quest, whether tied into the main questline or just a trivial matter, fits within the world and doesn't feel disjointed or forced.

The graphics are certainly a huge step up from the original, and still hold up well as of this review (May 2015). I have a AMD 7970 3gb card, and still can't even run this game on 'true' max settings - mind you, the only thing holding me back is the 'Ubersampling' option, which looks unreal, but cuts framerate to a halt on most systems. It's reserved for the 'best of the best' and not many can run it, even today. Aside from that setting, the Witcher II is still beautiful in every respect. The coastline city of Flotsam feels salty and dirty. The nearby marshes displays a sticky, dense fog that utters caution within the unknown. Details such as these are scattered throughout, and you'll never find yourself tired of the eye candy.

For those who played the original, the combat is a huge breath of fresh air in comparison. Gone is the timed left clicking jumbled mess, replaced by real time combat. You can light attack, heavy attack, or block/riposte. That's it. Despite this well-needed change, however, the fighting can get rather intense, especially on harder difficulties (I played on Dark). Dodge (basically roll) is your best friend. You will find yourself rolling out of harm's way so often, it's not even funny. Roll or die, that's about what it comes down to. 95% roll, 5% swordfighting. Apparently Sonic the Hedgehog is Geralt's spirit animal.

All the original Signs are back - Aard, Yrden, Quen, Igni, and Axii. In this game, Quen is your best friend. It will save your life countless times - my advice is to invest in upgrading it early. That said, there is a simple yet effective skill tree for Geralt's Signs and other abilities, split into four parts - Training, Swordsmanship, Signs, and Alchemy. Allocate points to the playstyle you like - you'll typically never level them all, so choose wisely.

Briefly touching on loot here - swords and armor are much more plentiful than the first game, which is nice. However those who import Witcher 1 saves will find that their imported content won't last long until a trade in, which is disappointing, especially with one particular weapon you acquire from the first game that its storyline seemed to hold in high regard.

The story is certainly good, and not too over the top (well, aside from a detail or two). Geralt's choices have much weight in this game, and you'll find more impactful choices than in the first iteration. Also included are various ways to get information in the dialogue options - persuasion (Axii), intimidation, and so forth. I'm not sure if its based on your current skills or a random number roll, but its a fun take on the 'click to ask X question' bit.

My only real gripe with this game, other than the occasional dodgy combat roll, is the Steam achievements. The game practically forces you to play twice to get absolutely every achievement. 100%'ers, beware. The insane mode alone is risky - one death and your save games become null and void.

Overall, this is an tremendously enjoyable sequel. Not as long as the first, but it has depth and production quality. Definitely worth a playthrough or two! (Note: This game has 'something after the credits'. Stick with it!)

reviewText:
By far one of the best games I've played. It has it's problems, but they don't take away from the game enough to ruin the experience in any meaningful manner. It has a slight old school feel to it as well, which I liked very much. Feels good to die over and over and over again in a game like this for a change as well :)

You get to solve how to beat the game, learn it, and then finally beat it when you've figured it out, which reminded me of some good games from the past. Way past, that is... This game also respects the players intelligence and maturity, and won't try to hand you everything sugar coated.

And then there's the story, and the different branches of it. It definitely surprised me how much of a difference your choice might make in the game! It won't make it obvious either, so if you don't play the game again, or check the differences on a video, you have no idea what the changes are, how big they are, and how much they affect your playthrough.

Certainly recommended for anyone interested in fantasy, rpg, good story, or just a good gaming experience.

reviewText: The Witcher 2 is a vast improvement over its predecessor, and, as the franchise is known for, has many new and variable tropes for a Fantasy RPG game. To highlight some of the game's best features, The Witcher 2's combat is reminiscent of Batman: Arkham Asylum, but requires far greater skill and preparation. The only complaint is that the game takes too fondly to the objectification of most, if not all, of it's female characters. reviewText: Geralt of Rivia, aka Gwynbleidd, the White Wolf, the Butcher of Blaviken, is the son of a sorcerer and a warrior subjected to mutations and rigorous sword and sorcery training as a child. Therefore he became a monster slayer, a mercenary known as a witcher that wanders the world seeeking work. His friend, and also a bard, Dandelion recounts his adventures as ballads and poems of the most famous witcher against monster and other evils thrown against him by fate. Geralt is not a good man, as Dandelion says himself, but he tries to maintain his humanity. He does not believe in destiny but he acts as a balance while using his steel swords against human adversaries and the silver sword to slice through monsters alike. In The Witcher 2, Geralt is mistakenly confused as a Kingslayer and as so must search for the real Kingslayer to bring him to his justice. You will face many creatures and monsters, elves and dwarves, and you will have to choose who are your allies and who will feel the wrath of your blade. Geralt is always searching for his lost past and to help him, he can count on his friends the sorcerer Triss Merigold, the bard Dandelion, the dice poker addicted Zoltan, and others that might or might not help him in his endevour. A truely epic tale, that deserves all the praise it got and more to come when Geralt, once again, start wandering the lands of the Northern Kingdoms and the Nilfgaardian Empire in search for more work and blood against all kinds of monsters. After all, that's what the most famous Witcher is after, isn't it ? Maybe not.

reviewText:
Great game. One of, if not the best RPG i have played. Its not as free as Skyrim or such but its beautifully made, the characters are strong characters you care about and the game is deep. At first it can be off putting, but stick at it and you will be rewarded, make potions, traps and use them.

The combat is frustrating at first, much like the first, and you will only start to get the hang of it half way through, but its great. As you progress you realise Geralt is agility based, and excells when you keep him moving and taking on the enemies without getting in the middle of them and slugging it out. Once you realise he is not a strong slugger but an agile fencer, combat all becomes a dream.

The story is complex, the decisions are also so, and though there isnt a right and wrong choice, each one has a strong repercussion. You shape the game as you play. Great fun, and at some points i was stuck for minutes trying to decide who to help or which path to take.

By the end of it you will be itching for part three, and if not, you are dont have a pulse or are a drowner...

4 Thumbs up.

reviewText:
The Consipracy
CD Project RED have sold their souls in exchange for creating perfect digital art.

The Original Classic
I remember back then, when the first Witcher came out it was something refreshing, captivating, even good, but still it wasn’t spectacular, despite some people calling it a new best RPG. Among its great strengths in story, quests, art and music it definitely had glaring issues: most notably, some annoying (to the point of being silly) combat moves and the fact that a good two thirds of it is spent in some sort of swamps, sewers and similar-looking dungeons.

There was no hint of something huge coming ahead.

Enter the Mighty Sequel
But suddenly and unexpectedly, The Witcher 2: Assassin of Kings is upon us. And here I am, trying to review it with my jaw dropped and dangling somewhere around my knees.

You are Geralt, a witcher — a professional monster slayer caught in a midst of political conflict, intrigue and soon after that, on a long quest to clear your good name and discover more pieces in attempt to solve a puzzle of Wild Hunt and your dark past.

Now this is something like ubelievable upgrade over previous installement, unmatched by anything in recent history. Everything you can possibly think of have been drastically improved, expanded and taken to breathtaking levels of visuals, music and sound. All environments are unique and are extremely rich in details: there’s no copy-paste ever.

The characters, even NPCs, are alive, deep and interesting. There’s no other RPG where you would stop just to listen to NPC talk and smile at some story they tell each other. Every place, every spot, be it in town or outside, has an event connected to it and some amazing quest you can take on: escape from prison (be a master of stealth, or you can make it a little rough), participate in an assault on rebellious town alongisde king and teach his stupid son some good lesson, prevent military abuse of innocent civillians by beating an officer in a one-on-one swordfight, and get away with it because your king favors you so much; visit abandoned and haunted asylum to calm down the spirits of its victims and learn about its grim past, uncover treason and crime, take a taste of dirty medieval town life by participating in brawls, dice poker and arm wrestling games — and earn some additional coin with that!

But There’s Much More!
Meet mages, trolls (friendly and not so much), fight a giant Cthulhu with a sorceress by your side, join elves in their guerilla struggle against humans, assist dwarves and visit their mysterious town hidden somewhere deep in the mountains or, if you rather prefer that, stay in a dirty human military camp and become a new star of its colloseum-like fighting arena. The choice is always yours: so be prepared to take it and face the consequences (or enjoy them :-).

Combat
And did I even mention how great fights can be? Devise your tactics, approach and hunt monsters: all different, inhabiting their own areas and requiring unique means to successfully kill; pursue finest gear upgrades to assist yourself in your dirty job. Harvest for ingredients during your trips outside to brew and drink awesome poisions (of a witcher sort) and acquire inhuman powers for a short amount time. Buy materials, schematics and construct deadly traps, bombs and daggers to leave your enemies no chance. Approach several knights that dared to threaten you and perform a powerful finisher move, killing them all at once. Redirect arrows back at your enemies, use powerful witcher magic tricks to trap or stun your foes: block, riposte, perform a quick roll away, then jump and cut your unfortunate foe through while he recovers from a good blast of your yrden (not a typo). You have to fight dirty: you have to fight like a witcher.

And all that above is just barely one third of what is in store for you.

Conclusion
I have no idea how CDPR were able to pull that all off.

(Disregard my hours, I own it from elsewhere.)

* * *

[A blast of fire from dragon’s breath]

— Witcher, how do you fight something like THIS?!
— You don’t, you run.
— Some professional you are!

Outstanding.

reviewText:
Geralt of Rivia has returned, and with warm welcome. The Witcher series is becoming one of my favorites within my list of fictional sagas, and this game certainly delivers on all fronts.

Assassins of Kings pulls no punches. It starts off with an incredibly beautiful CGI introduction that rivals even the best studios. Once you start the game, you're thrown right into war, and the rollercoaster ride hasn't even reached the first hill at this point. Geralt's adventures are plentiful - every quest, whether tied into the main questline or just a trivial matter, fits within the world and doesn't feel disjointed or forced.

The graphics are certainly a huge step up from the original, and still hold up well as of this review (May 2015). I have a AMD 7970 3gb card, and still can't even run this game on 'true' max settings - mind you, the only thing holding me back is the 'Ubersampling' option, which looks unreal, but cuts framerate to a halt on most systems. It's reserved for the 'best of the best' and not many can run it, even today. Aside from that setting, the Witcher II is still beautiful in every respect. The coastline city of Flotsam feels salty and dirty. The nearby marshes displays a sticky, dense fog that utters caution within the unknown. Details such as these are scattered throughout, and you'll never find yourself tired of the eye candy.

For those who played the original, the combat is a huge breath of fresh air in comparison. Gone is the timed left clicking jumbled mess, replaced by real time combat. You can light attack, heavy attack, or block/riposte. That's it. Despite this well-needed change, however, the fighting can get rather intense, especially on harder difficulties (I played on Dark). Dodge (basically roll) is your best friend. You will find yourself rolling out of harm's way so often, it's not even funny. Roll or die, that's about what it comes down to. 95% roll, 5% swordfighting. Apparently Sonic the Hedgehog is Geralt's spirit animal.

All the original Signs are back - Aard, Yrden, Quen, Igni, and Axii. In this game, Quen is your best friend. It will save your life countless times - my advice is to invest in upgrading it early. That said, there is a simple yet effective skill tree for Geralt's Signs and other abilities, split into four parts - Training, Swordsmanship, Signs, and Alchemy. Allocate points to the playstyle you like - you'll typically never level them all, so choose wisely.

Briefly touching on loot here - swords and armor are much more plentiful than the first game, which is nice. However those who import Witcher 1 saves will find that their imported content won't last long until a trade in, which is disappointing, especially with one particular weapon you acquire from the first game that its storyline seemed to hold in high regard.

The story is certainly good, and not too over the top (well, aside from a detail or two). Geralt's choices have much weight in this game, and you'll find more impactful choices than in the first iteration. Also included are various ways to get information in the dialogue options - persuasion (Axii), intimidation, and so forth. I'm not sure if its based on your current skills or a random number roll, but its a fun take on the 'click to ask X question' bit.

My only real gripe with this game, other than the occasional dodgy combat roll, is the Steam achievements. The game practically forces you to play twice to get absolutely every achievement. 100%'ers, beware. The insane mode alone is risky - one death and your save games become null and void.

Overall, this is an tremendously enjoyable sequel. Not as long as the first, but it has depth and production quality. Definitely worth a playthrough or two! (Note: This game has 'something after the credits'. Stick with it!)

reviewText:
Before we proceed, understand that I actually like the gameplay in The Witcher 2. In fact, it's exceptional. Combat is easy to play yet hard to master – an elusive quality in action RPG combat mechanics – with plenty of difficulty and interesting combat scenarios. By the end of the incredibly well put-together tutorial, you'll feel like you honestly participated in medieval siege. A rich and complex crafting system underpins plenty of gameplay interactions and makes many of the incidental bits of junk you collect through the game have real value. And on top of all of this, The Witcher 2 is one of those rare RPGs that flirts with having real consequence to player decisions throughout the dialogue.

Thus, I feel I have to give The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings a good review score; by every objective standard of game design, development, and production values, it is an excellent game. I cannot recommend it unreservedly, however, as a few things about the game never quite clicked into place for me. I found myself, at the end of it, more stricken by some of the evident gaps in story and gameplay direction than enthusiastic for the inevitable sequel that, presumably, will tie together the numerous loose ends of the storyline.

The first Witcher was a game that I had a very hard time playing through. On the one hand, I loved the writing and variety of choice available throughout the dialogue and intrigue portions of the game; on the other hand, most of the momentary gameplay was painfully overcomplicated and obtuse. Any game requiring that I explicitly enter combat mode and then explicitly choose a stance before I can start wailing on dudes loses points in my book. The Witcher 2 eschews many of the more glaring flaws of the original game—a more streamlined UI, a closer camera so you can really see what's going on, and a combat system that emphasizes skill are all welcome additions to the series.

There are some distinct flaws in the gameplay, though nothing major. The first and most obvious one is how side quest objectives are communicated. The Witcher 2 has joined the slew of recent games that basically lead you through the objectives to complete side quests (and, actually, main quests) by hand. While I have some objections to that in general, my complaint in this case is more about some of the little gaffes in how that's presented.

The next major flaw in the gameplay is that autosaving is used in the game, but not always in intelligent ways. At some boss fights, the game will autosave right before the big introduction cut-scene of the boss. This makes sense if you walk away from the game for a few days after dying to the monster once; but if you're like me, and try again... several times... then needing to blunder through the cut-scene time and again becomes a real nuisance.

The third major flaw is that there are unique gameplay modes – such as stealth – which will activate contextually, but you are explicitly told to enter them. Since the game decides when you enter into the mode, why are you telling me to go into the mode? What button is that? Not a big deal by any means, but a little irritation all the same.

Graphically and aurally, the Witcher 2 is a very well put-together game. Lush visuals, fantastic texture work, great visual effects, and clear iconography keep the game attractive.

The music is, by and large, very fitting, and the sound design tactfully places you in the middle of the events of the game. Lots of nice little touches – folks chopping away at wood in a little village, the crumbling of nearby rocks as you climb down a cliff face, or the occasional snap of twigs as you tromp through the forest – pop out of the speakers regularly. Voice acting is also quite good.

I think I take the most issue with the writing and character design. By and large, the Witcher series has a very dim view of most people. Just about everyone is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in The Witcher 2; even Geralt's sorceress girlfriend, the character who the writers tried hardest to make sympathetic, comes off as a catty, jealous ♥♥♥♥♥ at times. It's not that I believe people are always nice and friendly, but when there's not a single decent person to talk to, it gets hard to take any of the characters seriously.

The other side of this is that some of the best written, most charismatic and genuinely fun characters to be around don't last terribly long. This is made abundantly clear by the end of the tutorial. Apparently in Witcher world, fun people aren't fit to live.

By the end of the game, I found myself left with a distinctly ashen taste in my mouth; the victories are left hollow and incomplete. Partially because the ending doesn't fully resolve the numerous sub-plots of the game, but also because the storyline felt arbitrary and disconnected. The Witcher's style – weirdly dark and artificially edgy, especially for a fantasy title – creates disjointed storylines that, even when the promised ending occurs, are a letdown.

I also might mention that The Witcher 2 represents a... particular view of women. If you are comfortable seeing women portrayed as little more than ♥♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥, then this is the game for you! If, on the other hand, you find the lack of strong female characters in games to be irritating, then this really isn't for you. Triss and Ves, two of the notable female characters of the game, don't count, by the way; both spend most of their screen-time in form-fitting outfits, prancing their overly shapely asses about the focus point of the camera and generally requiring Geralt's manly help to accomplish much of anything.

Despite all the little flaws and caveats, The Witcher 2 is, ultimately, a fantastic game; any fan of darker, more consequentialist fiction will find themselves right at home. Nevertheless, those of you looking for something more upbeat, more uplifting – and frankly, less draining to play – will want to look elsewhere. The Witcher 2 is bittersweet.

reviewText:
I was introduced into the Witcher world starting with Witcher 3: Wild Hunt (if you havn't picked this up already, what are you waiting for?  It's one of the best games ever made).  After experiencing the incredible gift from the heavens that is Witcher 3 I decided to go back and play the first two installments of the franchise.

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings at first glance did not look particularly amazing(at least compared to Witcher 3), but after I got into it a bit, I realized that this game was quite good.

Siding with Roche or Iorveth at the end of Chapter 1 completely changes how the rest of the game plays out.

Story: 8/10  Mechanics: 4/10 Soundtrack: 9/10 Graphics: 9/10
Here is a quick rundown of some pros and cons:

Pros:
- Captivating and interesting storyline.
- Beautiful world
- Your choices matter!  (Even sidequests that appear insignificant can have a significant outcome on the storyline.)
- Awesome soundtrack

Cons:
- Quite poor interfacing issues (detailed below)
- A so-so combat system (also detailed below)
- Annoying navigation mechanics

While this game is awesome as a whole, it does have its flaws.  One of its biggest flaws is its combat system.  The combat system is a bit difficult to learn, but once you have learned it, it shouldn't be as much as a burden on you.  The combat system could be accurately described as inefficient, to say the least.  When first starting the game, the game seems ridiculously difficult at times simply because it is impossible to find decent gear early on.  Later on, however, it is much easier to buy/craft better gear, which then makes the difficulty a bit more manageable.  The auto-targetting system can be a real pain at times.  In most games, when you face an opponent and press the attack button/key, your character attacks that opponent.  That is not the case in this game.  Geralt will sometimes attack a random opponent if you are in the midst of a group of enemies.  Also, dodging enemy attacks can become very difficult when fighting groups of enemies, not because it is difficult to avoid them, but because the roll mechanic often times will not roll you in the direction you are wanting to roll to.  Sometimes I would try to dodge roll backwards, and I would instead go forwards, and therefore be killed by a horde of enemies.  All of these flaws mentioned above CAN be avoided with a bit of practice.  It's a shame you have to battle the mechanics, but it is what it is.

The navigation system can become particulary annoying at times.  There were many points in the game where I asked myself, Where in the world do I need to go next?"  Sometimes it would take me up to half an hour to find the answer to that question.  The minimap does show you where to go most of the time

votesHelpful: once I got used to the sketchy mechanics
votesTotal: I really loved this game.\n\n7/10"

reviewText:
Before we proceed, understand that I actually like the gameplay in The Witcher 2. In fact, it's exceptional. Combat is easy to play yet hard to master – an elusive quality in action RPG combat mechanics – with plenty of difficulty and interesting combat scenarios. By the end of the incredibly well put-together tutorial, you'll feel like you honestly participated in medieval siege. A rich and complex crafting system underpins plenty of gameplay interactions and makes many of the incidental bits of junk you collect through the game have real value. And on top of all of this, The Witcher 2 is one of those rare RPGs that flirts with having real consequence to player decisions throughout the dialogue.

Thus, I feel I have to give The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings a good review score; by every objective standard of game design, development, and production values, it is an excellent game. I cannot recommend it unreservedly, however, as a few things about the game never quite clicked into place for me. I found myself, at the end of it, more stricken by some of the evident gaps in story and gameplay direction than enthusiastic for the inevitable sequel that, presumably, will tie together the numerous loose ends of the storyline.

The first Witcher was a game that I had a very hard time playing through. On the one hand, I loved the writing and variety of choice available throughout the dialogue and intrigue portions of the game; on the other hand, most of the momentary gameplay was painfully overcomplicated and obtuse. Any game requiring that I explicitly enter combat mode and then explicitly choose a stance before I can start wailing on dudes loses points in my book. The Witcher 2 eschews many of the more glaring flaws of the original game—a more streamlined UI, a closer camera so you can really see what's going on, and a combat system that emphasizes skill are all welcome additions to the series.

There are some distinct flaws in the gameplay, though nothing major. The first and most obvious one is how side quest objectives are communicated. The Witcher 2 has joined the slew of recent games that basically lead you through the objectives to complete side quests (and, actually, main quests) by hand. While I have some objections to that in general, my complaint in this case is more about some of the little gaffes in how that's presented.

The next major flaw in the gameplay is that autosaving is used in the game, but not always in intelligent ways. At some boss fights, the game will autosave right before the big introduction cut-scene of the boss. This makes sense if you walk away from the game for a few days after dying to the monster once; but if you're like me, and try again... several times... then needing to blunder through the cut-scene time and again becomes a real nuisance.

The third major flaw is that there are unique gameplay modes – such as stealth – which will activate contextually, but you are explicitly told to enter them. Since the game decides when you enter into the mode, why are you telling me to go into the mode? What button is that? Not a big deal by any means, but a little irritation all the same.

Graphically and aurally, the Witcher 2 is a very well put-together game. Lush visuals, fantastic texture work, great visual effects, and clear iconography keep the game attractive.

The music is, by and large, very fitting, and the sound design tactfully places you in the middle of the events of the game. Lots of nice little touches – folks chopping away at wood in a little village, the crumbling of nearby rocks as you climb down a cliff face, or the occasional snap of twigs as you tromp through the forest – pop out of the speakers regularly. Voice acting is also quite good.

I think I take the most issue with the writing and character design. By and large, the Witcher series has a very dim view of most people. Just about everyone is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in The Witcher 2; even Geralt's sorceress girlfriend, the character who the writers tried hardest to make sympathetic, comes off as a catty, jealous ♥♥♥♥♥ at times. It's not that I believe people are always nice and friendly, but when there's not a single decent person to talk to, it gets hard to take any of the characters seriously.

The other side of this is that some of the best written, most charismatic and genuinely fun characters to be around don't last terribly long. This is made abundantly clear by the end of the tutorial. Apparently in Witcher world, fun people aren't fit to live.

By the end of the game, I found myself left with a distinctly ashen taste in my mouth; the victories are left hollow and incomplete. Partially because the ending doesn't fully resolve the numerous sub-plots of the game, but also because the storyline felt arbitrary and disconnected. The Witcher's style – weirdly dark and artificially edgy, especially for a fantasy title – creates disjointed storylines that, even when the promised ending occurs, are a letdown.

I also might mention that The Witcher 2 represents a... particular view of women. If you are comfortable seeing women portrayed as little more than ♥♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥, then this is the game for you! If, on the other hand, you find the lack of strong female characters in games to be irritating, then this really isn't for you. Triss and Ves, two of the notable female characters of the game, don't count, by the way; both spend most of their screen-time in form-fitting outfits, prancing their overly shapely asses about the focus point of the camera and generally requiring Geralt's manly help to accomplish much of anything.

Despite all the little flaws and caveats, The Witcher 2 is, ultimately, a fantastic game; any fan of darker, more consequentialist fiction will find themselves right at home. Nevertheless, those of you looking for something more upbeat, more uplifting – and frankly, less draining to play – will want to look elsewhere. The Witcher 2 is bittersweet.

reviewText:
Really interesting storyline and characters, and actually manages to make you feel emotionally attached to them. An awesome RPG that deals with difficult topics such as racism and sex in a very mature and adult way. Combat is incredibly hard to begin with - it has an enormous learning curve for people who haven't played the original game, but it is the unforgiving combat and reliance on quicksaving that makes it such a challenging and enjoying game. As with any other good RPG, the lore is intriguing, the characters are varied and engaging, and the choices the player makes will have real impact in the future. Graphical fidelity is still top-notch desite being a slightly older title than new games. Overall a timeless classic, and a great example of how other games in this genre should be.

TL/DR - 10/10 would highlly recommend.
(Please note, the time played above is only whilst logged in online, but including offline time it probably adds up to about 30 hours so far :P)

reviewText: The Witcher 2 is an exemplarary sequel that manages to build upon the strengths of the Witcher 1, namely it's combat mechanics and plot twists, while addressing and improving on it's predecessor's flaws . An outstanding Role Playing Game, no two replays of this game will ever be the same. In the Witcher 2, you are thrust into the character of Geralt of Rivia, famed monster slayer and unintended savior of a king, where you must make the decisions that alter the fates of not only the protagonist but the world and its many characters about him. Its a compelling narrative about maintaining neutrality in a world that is morally ambiguous and deceptive. You will feel the sting of unintended consequences, and with a variety of supporting characters, all whose lives and motivations you will come to understand, decisions in this game are not made lightly . Aside from its storyline, the actual mechanics of the gameplay are superbly executed. Combat is visceral and tactical. Magic, Alchemy, and swordplay are your means of defeating your enemies, and the Witcher 2 introduces a menagerie containing all sorts of monsters, both fantastically gargantuan & sometimes human, whose strengths/weaknesses must be taken into account, especially on the hardest of difficulties. In the end, the Witcher 2 is a satisfying video game with a storyline that leaves it's impression upon you because of it's relation to your impact as Geralt. I'm optimistic about this franchise and look forward to future sequels.

reviewText:
Performance:

Really impressed with how well-made the new engine is. Loads faster(which is kind of surprising because the first game's load times weren't even long), stutters less, and, of course, looks prettier. And I mean much prettier. You don't expect games that look this much better than their prequels to actually perform better than them.

The only things about it that I don't like are the differed rendering(alternate form of rendering that only supports [and works] [with] a form of anti-aliasing that has been specifically coded into the game, cancelling out any kind of AA forced on from your graphics control panel. Use SweetFX for AA.), sharpness filter(you'll wanna turn it off in your user config, but make sure to force Anisotrophic Filtering on), and the bloom. The bloom.. I usually am ok with bloom in my games, but I had to turn this game's off. There is just too much of it. For my eyes, anyway.

Graphics settings:
Many graphics settings available for tweaking. There's a lot you can make changes to that will help the game run better on your rig, if it needs it

Controls:
Controls are greatly improved. Dodging actually works consistently, unlike in the last game. Same with parrying. Same with attacking. I remember instances in the first Witcher where the system sometimes wouldn't let me attack opponents if they were close to me or surrounded me or just didn't let me attack them(while not stunned, etc). When attacking, you use either the left or right mouse button. Either are for heavy or light attacks. Is not like the first Witcher where you select an attack style and click on a foe. The buttons are the styles, so they have to be used/pressed after each attack. Can be combined.

They took out the feature that let's you press/hold a button/key to highlight/display whatever in view can be interacted with, as well as the the feature that's you select what you want to interact with the cursor, while you hold/press a button. It's not that big of a deal not having it, but you now have to just run up to something you see, and click on it to do whatever with it.

Gameplay:
Am a few hours into the game, but can say it's very much like the first. Only, better.

Combat is same, but more engaging. Also kinda harder(but I was playing on Dark/Insane difficulty.). You can meditate anywhere(no fireplaces/characters needed) that wouldn't be considered dangerous(out of battle, not in the presence of enemies). Inside or outside.

So far, the choice system is still here. I've been in situations in the game where I could, as an example, stop a crime or let it follow through. There are also sub-choices, which can sometimes be made after main choices have been made. Good/bad/etc ones are available.

EDIT:

Overall:
Have since spent more hours playing the game and am enjoying it. The story is very much still that of The Witcher's, and the gameplay is very fun. Good combat, and there more options for interacting with characters you encounter than there were in last Witcher game.

The game feels like it was made on PC, which is awesome. Same as the last game. Same level of detail in the enviornments, great graphics, and doesn't feel like some technically-constrained console port.

Money. The struggle is real in TW1. You NEED to go hunt down x Monster to make that cash. You need to bar fight and play Dice sometimes. I always really felt like I was truly hunting monsters as a profession, because I -had- to do what I could to make scratch.

reviewText:
This is my favorite RPG of all time. FULL STOP. You are hearing this from someone who played Planescape Torment, System Shock 2, Baldur's Gate, Fallout, and so on...

The amount of meaningful choices in this game is immense, you can even change 2 entire chapters of this game just because of ONE choice. The story is really intriguing, filled with political and racial conflict, while still maintaining a very personal feel and with some great characters to accompany you on this journey.

The combat is probably the most divisive element of the game, some will enjoy it (like I did), and others won't (at least it's a better combat system than the one in the first Witcher).

Technically, it still holds up today, and this was released in 2011, although some animations are a bit robotic, but that is something omnipresent on RPG's, so I let it pass. Both the voice acting and music are great.

Honestly, if you like RPG's, just buy this, it has some insane replay value, great modding comunity, and you can catch it on sale on Steam regularly.

Must Own!!!!

reviewText: Haunting and atmospheric just like the first in the series, and very fun and challenging to play through. The series seems to be becoming more action/adventure oriented than an RPG meant for purists, but what this game does it does very well. The combat system has become more oriented toward player skill rather than Geralt's attributes, but this turned out to be pretty fun once I got the hang of the controls. Branching storylines encourage replayability, as in the first game. At first I had a problem with the excessive use of bloom and shader effects, though these things are implemented far better and more artistically after the first chapter, so I suggest everyone keep these settings enabled. Overall this is a very well-written and clever game and I would recommend it to fans of the first game or fans of the fantasy fiction genre in general. You won't be disappointed!

reviewText:
Fanastic game, graphics are beautiful and the environments stunning, characters are very detailed and each one feels unique (unlike the identikit ones on Skyrim that are all voiced by the same 3 people) It's linear, yes, but thats because it has a story to tell and wants you to fully immerse yourself in the experience. Some big decisions to make throughout the game that will change how the story pans out, and I will definately be playing through it again to get the other endings.

This one will be tough on your graphics card, even some of the newer ones at max settings may struggle a little, but as you can see from the screens it is a gorgeous looking game.

My only dislike was the whole potions and meditating thing, wasn't a fan of that really, but other than that this game is a must play for any RPG or fantasy fan and I cannot wait for the finale, Witcher 3

reviewText:
It's certainly a Badass Action/RPG but considering it's a Sequel, I gotta compare it to the original.

7/10 as a Sequel - 8 or 9/10 if it were an original IP.

-Can't stumble around drunk.
-No nude cards.
-No Sky! Big deal for me. I want stars and ♥♥♥♥. There are some...clouds...I guess...sorta?
-Boring companions. At first I was hype to see Dandilion and the Dwarf, but they end up just hanging around not saying ♥♥♥♥. You interacted a lot more with your homies in TW1 and there was some funny stuff, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Voice Acting aside/included.
-Crazy bad texture pop-in. Still one of the best looking games around, but the pop-in nearly ruins it.
-Dice board isn't as pretty. Just a nitpick, and obviously just my opinion.

The main thing that made The Witcher 1 an incredible game was an actual sense of being a Monster Hunter. TW2 does a good job in many ways, but not in the one that I think was most effective.

Money. The struggle is real in TW1. You NEED to go hunt down x Monster to make that cash. You need to bar fight and play Dice sometimes. I always really felt like I was truly hunting monsters as a profession, because I -had- to do what I could to make scratch.

The other element in TW1 is just being a Witcher in general...potions. I had to max the difficulty of course but, drinking potions and using spells was a huge deal in TW1. Before you enter a cave, you make sure you're set with potions. You take a moment to prepare and drink up before going in. It mattered. At first I thought it was lame. He felt weak, and it seemed pathetic that he needed potions to even fight.

But, I adjusted to the fact that he's a Witcher" and that's how they roll
date: because normal people can't even drink the potions without damn near dying. I mean
recommended: I'm sure he can whoop anybody's ♥♥♥ without the potions
hoursPlayed: but these are monsters. It made sense when I really thought about it
voteText:
and added to the strategy.

Combat too..not everyone agrees but I thought combat in TW1 was sick as ♥♥♥♥. Loved the stances.

Game just had this "vibe" that you can't really put into words as well.

Thank you for reading my TL:DR TW1 review."

Supposedly one of the biggest & best RPGs ever, well I certainly went in with some expectations reading that.

The game started off great, sure there was a lot to take in, but the boss battles were tough, there was tons of stuff to experience & everything looked terrific.  Unfortunately as you progress the boss battles become too easy, the isn't really that much in the world to explore & the game seems over too quickly (well it feels quick even though it was +30 hours for me).

Had the boss battles remained tough, crafting provided more reward & the ending not so abrupt W2 would be a solid 9/10 for me.  Unfortunately these issues plus a known quit to desktop issue you have to google to find a solution to leaves me at a 7/10.

reviewText:
This is a good RPG with some really impressive graphical and visual effects. Especially the lighting effects looks astonishing. The story is mature and rather complex, but I couldn't really appreciate it as much as others have done. Maybe it was because I haven't played the first game and therefore missed out on some parts of the overall story and the lore. Either way I thought it was a little bit too confusing at times, especially when the facial expressions and character animations wasn't very good.

I also thought that the menus could've been better - they often felt slow, unresponsive and very irritating.

But the thing that kept me playing was the superb combat! The feeling when you fought against a large number of enemies at the same time and you had to think tactical to survive was really rewarding!

Overall, I enjoyed the game but was a little disappointed with the story, mostly because I've heard a lot good things about it. I do recommend the game though, especially if you want to test what your computer is capable of.

With 46 hours of gameplay im finally reviewing this game.
The witcher 2 is a western hardcore rpg that takes place in a beautiful fantasy world with a lot of detail in it.
The thing that makes this game special is that its unique you have 2 swords 1 steel sword 1 silver sword you use the steel sword on humans and silver on monsters, while playing you can find herbs and other alchemy ingredients, which you can use to make bombs, oils and potions which are all essential for higher difficulty's. The pros of this game are

Beautifull graphics
Not holding your hand
The mature themes
The music
The beautifully crafted world
The combat
Its unique

The cons of this game are

There are a few bugs
Not really accesible for new players even on the lowest difficulty
The game crashes quite a few times
The optimization isnt great but its not terrible either
The economic system isnt that great


My conclusion is that this is a great game to have in your library since you can get it really cheap in sale and its deffinantly something that will keep you busy i give this game a 9.5/10

reviewText:
I am going to be honest, I had a trouble getting into this game. I've tried several times since the original release and EE release, but I just couldn't bear the missions in the first chapter.

But recently I just said - f**k it, let's blast through it. I bought a controller, which helped immensely with enjoying the game, it made the most important aspect of that kind of game - combat - smoother and pleasant. I turned Big Picture mode on my TV, and I breezed through it in a few days. I was having a blast. It was amazing.

I've never been a big fan of CRPGs/ARPGs but the story was fulfilling, combat was enjoyable, graphical fidelity and graphical design were astonishing, original voice acting was well done altough it had a few awkward and bad moments, and music was lovely.

It really is a great game, enjoyable for hardcore RPG fans and also for casual RPG fans.

The biggest gripe I have with this title is the repetitiveness of NPC's designs. In the first chapter it hadn't been noticeable, but after seeing the same body type and face for the 50th time in the chapter 2 and 3, it became noticeable, annoyingly so.



I have got to admit - I wasn't really hyped about Witcher 3 before playing W2. But now? Damn, I am so excited to know more about Wild Hunt - this menacing power of some sorts, which was only barely mentioned in Witcher 2.
[Story spoilers]
And what happened to Roche and Anais? To Yennefer? Who is going to stop Nilfgaard?

But I'm afraid that Witcher 3 will require a considerable upgrade of my PC.
