reviewText:
TL;DL - Game is so good. Combat is awesome. Good RPG element. A tale to be told.

7/10

Pro
+ Awesome sex scene
+ Awesome combat
+ Awesome character
+ Awesome story for main quest
+ Awesome crafting mechanic
+ Awesome graphic

Con
- Less sex
- Less secondary quest
- Less monster hunting
- Less fun mini game.
- Graphic can be too bright/contrast
- Nerf of potion, oil etc.

Full Review Second game in The Witcher series from CDPR.
You will continue to play as Geralt, a witcher, after the event of the first game.

You can tell how much CDPR have put they effort on this game to improve from the first witcher.

The graphic is so awesome. Thanks for REDengine from CDPR themselves. It look better then most game these day.
The world setting and location fit the world of witcher nicely.
Combat have been improve a lot. More fluid and responsive. Really fun to play.
Crafting and overall game mechanic is a lot more easier.
These are the first few thing you will notice after 15 minutes in the game and you will get addicts to this game right off the bat.

The main story of The witcher 2 is more intense, more mature and come with really hard choice to choose.
Your decision can affect the whole game story. Make The witcher 2 have lot of replayability.
It deserve to play at least twice.

The charecters in The witcher 2 is also very interesting. You will learn to love or hate them as the story go.

BUT  I rate this game less then The Witcher 1 (I rate first one 8/10).
While gameplay and graphic have been improve a lot. The story of the witcher 2 not really appeal to me.
(Is it just me that like the story of TW1 then TW2. I don't really like political element in TW2. I think it's a bit too much and I feel like political don't fit well with the witcher story)
What really dissappoint me is secondary quest. There is less secondary quest to play in the witcher 2 and none of them is memorable. The monster contract in The witcher 2 is more deeper and harder to complete which I like but there is so little of them. Make it lost the feeling of being the witcher. There is also not much monster in the wild and not much variety.

I don't really like the mini game is this one too. Poker dice is hard to read, fist fighting become QTE and arm wrestling is way too easy. There is also no romance card to collect (AKA less sex).

The graphic is really good but at time it can be too bright and color and be too contrast. It does look beautiful but sometime it's just too much. Also, This maybe a tiny thing but the graphic and control option have to be adjust outside the game.

Potion is one of the most important part in The witcher. In the witcher 2 you can brew potion, crafting and meditating without bonfire BUT you can't drink potion while in combat!! And the duration of potion and other buff have been decrease a lot. I understand that CDPR try to balancing the game since the buff can be to OP (In the witcher 1 potion last many hours depand on what kind while The Witcher 2 last 10 minute). But with duration of potion nerf and need of meditating to drink potion make potion in witcher 2 almost useless. If you prepare and drink your potion first it can go out of effect while in cutscene or conversation and if fight happan immediatly you can't drink potion. I often found that duration is too short and not enought while explore the area. But good thing is you can brew/drink potion anytime and you can upgrade your skill or equipment to make duration longer. I just found it quite annoying to keep drinking potion.

Summary The witcher 2 overall is one of the best RPG experiance to have. Beautiful graphic and world setting. Very good combat and game mechanic is easy to understand. Deep story with hard choice to be made and lot of replayability.

I may complain in a few thing about The witcher 2 but maybe I adhere to The witcher 1 too much.

The witcher 2 is a must play in my opinion.

PS : Sorry for my english.

reviewText:
Really, really solid Action-RPG.

The story is engrossing, full of well-developed characters and locales. Many choices are made throughout the game, and all of them feel like a moral shade of grey, being much more interesting than the good-or-evil binary in some other games. The game feels like it covers only a small section of a much larger canvas, and it is always obvious that important events are happening around Geralt and company.

The world feels alive and lived-in, and there are many small details that draw you in. NPCs gather in town centers and taverns and banter between each other. Some of the dialog ends up repeated if you stick around one area too long, but it is written well and does not become grating. Creature design is good, and some of the larger ones are very intimidating. Monsters in the wild form packs and hunt and attack other monsters (and you).

The combat in this game is good, but not great. Most fights can be either rushed down quickly or kited around, getting in a few hits at a time. Strong attacks seem more effective than fast attacks almost all of the time, and I sorely missed the group" attacks from the first game. The signs are useful to varying degrees. I found myself using Quen
hoursPlayed: but Igni and Axii signs were hardly ever used. Preparing for combat by drinking potions and using sword oils is very important

reviewText:
Do yourself a favour and play this before The Witcher 3...
... Not because The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt wouldn't work as a standalone game. Actually it does, and it does it very well.

I got this game on sale for 2,99€ a few days back. My only problem with this game is that I have already finished The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt before starting this game. Truth be told, these games look much alike. So for a 2011 game The Witcher 2 looks great and feels great. If I had never played The Witcher 3 I would probably consider this one of the
greatest games I have ever played. The story, dialogue, acting, combat - all of it is there and it's good.

But here is the problem; none of it is quite as good as with The Witcher 3. If you have never played The Witcher 3 you wouldn't know all the tiny things you're missing when you're playing The Witcher 2. But if you already have, you got to admit that in comparison The Witcher 2 feels rather small, clunky, limiting and occasionally claustrophobically one dimensional. This is not exactly fault of the game itself, but because the sequel happens to be probably the best game ever made.

So do yourself a favour and don't do like I did. Don't go straight to The Witcher 3, but play this one (and even the first one if you can stomach the outdated experience) first or it will be very hard to come back. Personally I've found the story itself intriguing and craving more for the world of The Witcher. Right now, being used to the best coming back to something almost as good isn't quite cutting it anymore.

I will finish this game eventually, but I wish I had started from here, just because I would've enjoyed it more.

Regardless, this game is easily worth the money.

reviewText: The Witcher was a fantastic game. For some reason, the devs felt like they had to change the combat system and slow down the pacing of the sequel. I am sure the control changes were to appeal to the console market, and it was a big mistake. It completely ruins the game. Not only the controls overly complex and counterintuitive, but they are made worse by a very steep difficulty curve. This combined with the lack of clarity in the storytelling and what is far and away the worst menu system I have ever seen in a game and you wind up with a disappointing shadow of what could have been. I love the story and really wanted to experience it in its entirety, but could not do so due to the game's awful controls, terrible pacing and confusing menus. Also, as much as I like dialogue heavy games, this one overdoes it. Too much of a good thing. I can't count the number of times I've wished an npc would just shut up already. When you can sit down in a game for an hour or two and accomplish nothing, something is very wrong.

reviewText:
The Witcher 2 suffers from consolization through and through.

The plot, characters and overall art design are okay and the main premise (catching Letho to clear your name) is developed well enough and it's a better motivation that we had in the first game.
Unfortunately the whole experience is ruined by absolutely trash engine (the game runs worse on lower settings than the Witcher 3 on the highest does) and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gameplay. And while you would have thought that better character tree (three separate branches of character development) would deliver better outcome that the first Witcher, it's all irrelevant due to absolutely batshit crazy input lag and lack of direct control over your character. Every move you make, every swing you try to do needs about 0,5-1 second until it's actually performed. You don't really have control on which attack you will actually perform. Will it be a single swing? A pirouette? A chained attack? ♥♥♥♥ you, prepare for a surprise and a possible ♥♥♥♥ up of getting mauled to death by a bunch of monsters if your character decides to perform a fancy attack with jumping and rolling. You can't even cancel your moves, I mean, the ♥♥♥♥ is this ♥♥♥♥? Your ripostes will not activate at random, hey enjoying that 1/3 hp hit already because of some script hicup or other ♥♥♥♥?
On a top of that add a really console-centring UI with awful feel on PC. Drinking a single potion is a chore. And this game needs you to care about drugs all the time, so you will enter meditation over and over again (because potions' duration times are significantly nerfed). The animations and transitions between game screens takes more time that the actual draggin potions to drink them.
If you decide to delve into an awful crafting system (don't do it), you will start to rip your hairs pretty fast, since the awful auto-aim makes every looting of crates piled one on another a real pain in the ♥♥♥. Are you trying to take just specific ingredients from this pile of chests in somebody's house? Tthere's no thievery system by the way and everyone will be happy for you robbing them from everything they've got - enjoying your immersive story telling yet? Well ♥♥♥♥ you, just take them all together and sell the rest to a vendor for 10 coins for half of your inventory capacity.
Also, never do a precise granade/knife aiming, since you will miss 90% of the time, even the knife just went through the guy's head.

I've tried to do a second playthrough before finishing the Witcher 3, but playing this game is like hitting your own balls with a hammer.

reviewText:
Overview:

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a fantasy RPG set in a medieval landscape.  The player controls Geralt of Rivia as he trys to uncover the truth behind the events that take place in the beginning of the game.  An expansive story awaits and is effected by the player's actions.  The choices you make really will effect the outcome of events.

Pros:

A great and detailed story.  The story is definitely the best aspect of this game.  There are a lot of important characters throughout the game who will shape events as they unfold.

Content.  There is a lot of content here.  Each area has a few side quests in addition to the main story quests.  Even if you just stick to the main quests, the story will take you around 30 hours.  Crafting is also available and can take a considerable amount of time.  If you want a break from the main game, an arena area is available with leaderboards.

Cons:

Crafting.  Don't bother trying to craft that really awesome armor set the vendor is selling.  For one, you will probably never get the money to even buy all the recipes.  If you do manage that, it can be quite time consuming to gather all the leather.  Each armor set comes with a sword recipe for your regular and silver sword.  The swords are the worst part of this crafted set.  They are really awesome for the current area, but require you to have the complete set equiped to use.  Each time you move to a new area in the game, the previous armor set recipes become unavailable.  So, if you spent time just crafting the swords and move to the next area, all that time and resources are now gone.  Crafting armor pieces can be pointless as better or equivalent items can be found by simply thoroughly exploring the area or gambling with random NPCs.  Other than potions and enhancements, crafting is just a waste of time.

Combat.  Although Geralt has access to a few spells in addition to swords, the combat is rather simple.  You can easily play the entire game just slashing as fast as you can and dodging away.  You can parry your opponent by waiting for them to attack, but this locks your character in place and is not advisable when taking on multiple opponents.  Since basically every fight has you facing multiple opponents, parrying can leave you open.

Story Presentation.  The story is pretty good, but sometimes it is not presented very well.  The player mainly controls Geralt but at times will very briefly control a side character.  This can happen at random times and can be better handled by just showing a cut scene.

Tech Issues.  The audio in the game is all over the place.  Sometimes character dialog will be very loud and other times a wisper.  I also did not care for the narrator's voice when transitioning to new areas.  When I had a lot of saves the game would continually crash when trying to load.

Level Design.  The world consist of mainly tight corridors with very little open space.  It would have been nice to have more room to roam around.

Conclusion:

The Witcher 2 presents a great story in a not so great way.  The levels feel claustrophobic, the combat can be very simple, and the crafting can be pointless.  If you put that aside, this is still a pretty good game.  There is a deep story here that can be guided by the player.  If you haven't played a serious RPG in awhile and are looking for something decent, play this.

Score: 8.1 / 10

reviewText:
The Witcher and The Witcher II are games that have a lot of character building.

This game is based on a set of novels by a Polish author and has become popular enough for 3 games. The 3rd will be out soon and the support for it is astounding.

I've fallen in love with Geralt of Rivia, a witcher, which are an order of people who were genetically modified as children to be faster, stronger, more resilient humans who can cast spells called signs to help with combat. They are monster hunters who stay neutral (or try to) through out their adventures.

Geralt is also the desire of pretty much every chick he runs across. He gets a lot of tail. Tastefully of course. But seriously this guy is a bush master.

So, the main combat style is sword fighting, which he is VERY good at, in many different ways.
Throughout the game, you're forced to make choices, which change the game in significant ways and give you different outcomes and endings. It's similar to Fallout or Mass Effect in this way. It still has a linear story line, with optional and required sub storylines.

It's written beautifully. I cannot WAIT for the 3rd and final game.

reviewText: The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a fantastic, epic spanning RPG, worthy of any PC Gamer’s eye.  Although the game is not without its fair share of technical blemishes Witcher 2 delivers a powerful punch to the player from the moment they click “Play”.  The atmosphere delivered in this title is very engrossing, and as such, Witcher 2 is able to pull the player in and never let go.  The graphics are superb, the art direction is creative and eye catching, and the writing is well delivered, never failing to entrench the player within the game’s vigorously delivered atmosphere.  Although challenging, The Witcher 2 is quite rewarding, delivering an experience like none other.  Most modern RPGs provide the player with two extremes, either absolutely satanic, or non-arguably angelic, and while these games tout their “you write your own story” technique, they fail in delivery.  This is where the Witcher 2 absolutely nails it.  I highly recommend this title.

reviewText:
I've played my fair share of RPGs. Both the good, such as KOTOR, and the bad. Yes, I'm looking at you Mass Effect 3. I wouldn't consider myself a hardcore RPG player, but this has to be one of the best games I've ever played.

First, the game itself is more of an action game with RPG elements. In this regard, it is a lot like ME, where all combat is realtime, and you aren't going to swing at someone, obviously hit them, and be told you missed, unlike its predecessor (although the first Witcher had miss animations). The gameplay is solid, and not quite like Mass Effect in that you have to keep moving instead of staying in cover. One nice thing is that you can glance at the lower left-hand corner to see the last few attacks and defends with their corrosponding damages.

Next, the story is just plain awesome. I can't say much, other than while it was well written, the story is a bit on the shorter side, but no matter, as there are enough areas to explore and quests to finish to keep you playing for a long time.

Also, the graphics are gorgeous, especially for 2011. They are, infact, much better than most games today.

Finally, I'd say that if there is ANYTHING to complain about with this game, it would be that you cannot edit video settings or controls outside of the launcher. However, this is a minor complaint, and can easily be overlooked.

Verdict: This game is a must have. As of the writing of this review, the game is only $4.00. I would gladly pay $40 for a game this well made.

PS. For those of you who decide this game is worth the money. CD PROJEKT RED left a little surprise" in the games files

recommended: if you know what I mean..."

reviewText:
If you are reading this review before I change my avatar (it may happen sooner or later) you will understand how much I love this game. I will be writing an honest review though, focusing on PRO and CON aspects of the game.

PRO

- Re-playability: you will never play this game the same way twice! Every stage of the storyline offers you a great variety of choices that will highly influence the world around you. You will be facing hard decisions, since the very beginning to the very ending of the game.

- Combat system: the combat system of The Witcher 2 is particular and interesting. You will be carrying two swords: a steel one for human targets and a silver blade for monsters. You need to decide which sword to use depending on the enemy you will be facing. In addition to this there is a number of tools, traps, ranged weapons you can use, potions you can drink that have to be prepared before the battle. Depending on the enemy you must, then, think at the perfect strategy to defeat it!

- Customization: upon leveling up you gain one point you can spend on one of the four perk paths: Witcher, Swordsmanship, Magic and Alchemy. You have to complete the first one to unlock the other three (which is not a problem). You can add a perk in every path regardless of the initial choice, but the more you advance in a path, the better abilities you will gain, it is another decision you have to take! :)

- Graphics: playing the Witcher 2 at max graphic renders you utterly speechless, the details, the motion blur, the texturing and modeling is almost flawless considering it is a 2011 game.

- Arena mode: this mode offers you lots of new hours of gameplay. You will have to kill waves of enemies, and with every wave completed you gain perk points and currency to improve yourself in order to face the next wave. Score, then, can be registered to compare it with other players.

CON

- Diffuculties gap: the easiest difficulty may make you finish the game even without the need of adding perks. Almost every enemy can be killed by normal sword slashes, while the hardest mode is an incredibly challenging mode. There is not a real midpoint.

- Identical NPCs: hardly you will find NPCs with their own unique features, apart from the characters you will interact with during the main storyline. Sometimes clothes and outfits are different, but the face model is the same. There are few base models being used in different towns (poor woman, poor man, noble woman, noble man, dwarf, male elf, female elf etc).

I definitely recommend this game, especially now that The Witcher 3 will be released next year. It is an amazing way to get familiar with the Witcher world, lore and system!

reviewText:
Overview:

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a fantasy RPG set in a medieval landscape.  The player controls Geralt of Rivia as he trys to uncover the truth behind the events that take place in the beginning of the game.  An expansive story awaits and is effected by the player's actions.  The choices you make really will effect the outcome of events.

Pros:

A great and detailed story.  The story is definitely the best aspect of this game.  There are a lot of important characters throughout the game who will shape events as they unfold.

Content.  There is a lot of content here.  Each area has a few side quests in addition to the main story quests.  Even if you just stick to the main quests, the story will take you around 30 hours.  Crafting is also available and can take a considerable amount of time.  If you want a break from the main game, an arena area is available with leaderboards.

Cons:

Crafting.  Don't bother trying to craft that really awesome armor set the vendor is selling.  For one, you will probably never get the money to even buy all the recipes.  If you do manage that, it can be quite time consuming to gather all the leather.  Each armor set comes with a sword recipe for your regular and silver sword.  The swords are the worst part of this crafted set.  They are really awesome for the current area, but require you to have the complete set equiped to use.  Each time you move to a new area in the game, the previous armor set recipes become unavailable.  So, if you spent time just crafting the swords and move to the next area, all that time and resources are now gone.  Crafting armor pieces can be pointless as better or equivalent items can be found by simply thoroughly exploring the area or gambling with random NPCs.  Other than potions and enhancements, crafting is just a waste of time.

Combat.  Although Geralt has access to a few spells in addition to swords, the combat is rather simple.  You can easily play the entire game just slashing as fast as you can and dodging away.  You can parry your opponent by waiting for them to attack, but this locks your character in place and is not advisable when taking on multiple opponents.  Since basically every fight has you facing multiple opponents, parrying can leave you open.

Story Presentation.  The story is pretty good, but sometimes it is not presented very well.  The player mainly controls Geralt but at times will very briefly control a side character.  This can happen at random times and can be better handled by just showing a cut scene.

Tech Issues.  The audio in the game is all over the place.  Sometimes character dialog will be very loud and other times a wisper.  I also did not care for the narrator's voice when transitioning to new areas.  When I had a lot of saves the game would continually crash when trying to load.

Level Design.  The world consist of mainly tight corridors with very little open space.  It would have been nice to have more room to roam around.

Conclusion:

The Witcher 2 presents a great story in a not so great way.  The levels feel claustrophobic, the combat can be very simple, and the crafting can be pointless.  If you put that aside, this is still a pretty good game.  There is a deep story here that can be guided by the player.  If you haven't played a serious RPG in awhile and are looking for something decent, play this.

Score: 8.1 / 10

reviewText: This game is one of my favorite RPGs of all time. It has a really strong and compelling narrative and offers you plenty of chances to make choices that feel like they have some weight to them, though, perhaps not as much as the first game. The characters are mostly interesting, and the character development is definitely there. One of my favorite things about the story and characters is the moral ambiguity of it all. There is no clear distinction of good and evil between any of the sides. Simply two perspectives of what's right. The combat feels pretty fluid and I greatly enjoyed it. I liked how alchemy worked in the game, too. It's unnecessary in the first two difficulties, but in the higher ones, you'll find yourself greatly crippled if not using it. You cannot use potions in combat, so that adds some strategy to it. The game is absolutely beautiful on ultra settings, and it still looks pretty great even on lowers ones. The environment does at least. Nothing seems out of place in the world, the enemies are well designed and plenty creepy at times. They did a great job crafting the world.\n\nThat doesn't mean it's without its issues, though. The combat does seem pretty fluid, but in higher difficulties you'll find yourself rolling endlessly across the ground with your foes in hot pursuit. Blocking is often times useless, and there is very noticeable input lag on occasion. There's also a noticeable disparity between easy and normal difficulties. Easy being ridiculously so, and normal for new players likely quite challenging in the beginning. Also, though I enjoyed how alchemy works, it also leads to an obvious issue that can break the fluidity/immersion of the game. Since you can't use potions outside of battle, this leads most people to entering a fight to see which potion they should use for which resistances or buffs, loading a quicksave, and then using the potion. I love the idea and how it fits into the Witcher lore, but it needs some work. Also, either a pro or a con depending on your preferences, but it's not really an open world, and there's very few side-quests. You go from hub to hub, each having a few explorable zones mainly comprised of small passages. As far as the side-quests go, there's around 8 or so for the first 2 acts, I believe. Not really all that many. It leads to it being a fairly short game as far as RPGs go. Mentioning the choices again, I loved how they were worked into the game and they did feel" weighty
date: though they didn't really mean much. You still end up in more or less the same situations with the same people doing the same things.\n\nAnd then there's the much touted "Maturity" of the game. Yes

reviewText: Unforgiving combat that emphasize strategy over button-mashing; unforgettable characters who are morally ambiguous in very human ways; and player choices that actually matter, makes The Witcher 2 a fantastic role-playing experience.\nThe Enhanced Edition has fixed some of the balancing issues from the first release and filled in some of the story, helping the overall pacing and to bridge the three acts together in a smoother way.\nFresh players might be helped by the new tutorial at the start of the game, as this is a game that has some old-school sensibilities in that it kind of assumes that you've read the game manual.

reviewText:
I'm not typically compelled to review games I purchase on Steam, but the Witcher 2 so thoroughly surprised me I had to say something.

I had long avoided the Witcher series out of dislike for the apparently cliche main character, but as there was an absence of good RPGs to play this summer I picked them up during the sale on a lark. The first game I played a couple chapters of, but ultimately couldn't get into it; I had played Neverwinter Nights to death earlier in my life, and the similarities of the Aurora engine were just so strong that I found myself burnt out.

So I booted up the Witcher 2. I was instantaenously amazed by the graphics, despite the game's age. The visual fidelity worked to support what felt like a living, breathing world, and within the first hour I was already hooked on the story. The characters, while suffering from stiff facial animations, are backed up by well-written dialogue and quality voice-acting. There is a moment early in the game where Geralt re-unites with his companions in an inn and, while the party meeting around a table" is a genre staple
date: the presentation was so well done I felt like I was in a Lord of the Rings scene.\n\nThe game's mechanics aren't quite as engrossing as its narrative. The combat is servicable
